However, the worst part is just how unnecessary it all is. If any product ever screamed of money-grabbing, this is it. The times the movie works directly correlates to when Stone and Garfield are sharing the screen, or when he's fully suited.

title: In the lesser of Spider-Man films
text: The Amazing Spider-Man is in the lesser Spider-Man movies but it is still a good Spider-Man movie, obviously when compared to Raimi's original it's not better but it doesn't have to be, it just had to be a good movie, and it was.The Amazing Spider-Man literally looks amazing, the cinematography and visuals are gorgeous, the special effects for Lizard are great and the action is very well done, Stan Lee's cameo was hilarious and Andrew Garfield is great as Spider-Man, the film has an awesome finale and a very sad death at the end of it.But here's the thing, TASM has one of the weirdest directing styles I've seen in a comic book movie, the editing is very fast paced at many parts and something about Andrew Garfield's Peter Parker just feels off, Gwen Stacy and Dr. Connors we're horribly underdeveloped and Emma Stone is really bad in this film, but that doesn't drag it down for me, and it's still good.Nonetheless, I'm gonna give The Amazing Spider-Man an A-

title: Faithful to comics
text: More faithful to the comics than the other film adaptations of the character. However, for me, the film focuses too much on the origin of Spiderman, which is more of the same. The lizard as a villain and the adaptation of Gwen Stacy was a great thing to see, and exploring the death of Peter's parents was interesting. Honorable mention for Peter vs. Flash, the scenes are much more credible than those of the original film (Let's face it, it was impossible for anyone to notice who the spider was)

title: A return to form
text: Feels far closer to the comics than the original trilogy ever did - Peter Parker's genius and wit have transferred to the big screen rather well (and made even more obvious by being sorely lacking in the original films). Garfield feels convincing, both as Parker and Spidey, and Ifans steals the show as Connors/The Lizard. When I heard about this re-boot initially I was skeptical, however the film has just proven how flawed the first 3 films were, and is quite frankly, Amazing (sorry). Roll on the sequel...

title: amazing spider man
text: Amazing spider man for me is far behind raimi trilogy in basiacly every way,starting with garfield version of spiderman,for me garfield was to good looking and to unnerdy for peter parker and in some ways even popular,which peter never was in comics and never acted that way,contuining the film has to many expocition and explaining almost everything and not leaving to audience to figured out themselves,and some cgi effects look prety weak and sloopy,the best thing is peter and gwen chemistry and their relationship,but in the end was little ruined by decisions and breaking promise by peter

title: AMAZING spiderman
text: This film is the reason for the phrase 're-boot'!Now I must start by saying I did not hate the original spiderman films and in fact still Think they are great iconic superhero films.That being said this new addition adds a great deal of emotional depth to Peter Parker and the spiderman franchise in general. So many people complain that the character has become weaker, but what everyone has to realise is, this is about a young adult who is only just becoming aware of his new powers and how to use them. Not only that but he is still trying to find his place in this world and battling many emotions such as love and revenge. How many of us can say we were fully established as the people we are now at such a young age?I feel the film also does a great job of showing just how hard it actually is to be a superhero by showing the injuries to Peter and how the city gets behind him to help him. (one of my favourite concepts of the spiderman comics). Admittedly also showcased in spiderman 2.In my opinion this film has added a great amount of story to this franchise and has planted the seed for many great epic sequels to come.I would just like to add that all the naysayers of this film complaining about many scenes being similar to the first film seem to be talking out their...... This film Is greatly different! There are a few similar scenes but then how many ways can you think of to say he was bitten by a radioactive spider and his uncle dies??? Really!!

title: Promises the 'untold story' but gives us largely the same as before; it just ends up being redundant and generic.
text: 'The Amazing Spider-Man (2012)' promises the 'untold story' and yet gives us largely the same origin as before, oddly borrowing some specific elements that surely wouldn't be included if they hadn't been in the '2002' incarnation, while removing most of the connecting tissue between the events and thus severely reducing their impact. Peter Parker - here, a skate-boarding hipster whose idea of awkward is to talk too much but always manage to say the right thing - is bitten by a random spider, that isn't set up as being genetically modified, while visiting a lab. Within a couple of scenes, he is crawling about the walls with ease. It's almost like they couldn't be bothered to retell the origin story and so decided to rush through it, making the entire endeavour rather redundant as it's almost assumed you've seen the prior trilogy anyway. Even when the web-slinging action starts - which is well-done for the most part and compounded by some believable visual effects - you just don't care. Plus, it doesn't help that the film is painfully generic, too, both in terms of the story-telling and the directing. At with least Raimi's trilogy, even when it was at its worst it was still interesting. It's worth noting, though, that Garfield and Stone are notably good in their roles. Their genuine chemistry elevates the movie, which is at its best whenever they share a scene. 5/10.

title: Exciting
text: Yes its amazing. Introducing Spidy again was difficult when we have already seen him in action over the past few years. Marc Webb has done a superb job in setting the storyline. Andrew Garfield did a good job in new avatar. Emma Stone looked cute playing Gwen Stacy. Dr. Curt Connors was really a bad-ass villain. The movie had a humour which was great . Good action sequences, not at all boring. The Movie is a must watch for all the Spiderman fans. One thing which i am still thinking is for whom was Rajit Ratha(Irrfan Khan)working. Now we have spidy back in new style lets wait for his next encounter with is new enemy. Who will it be, The Chameleon or The Vulture or The Jackal or Mysterio or Electro or J. Jonah Jameson.

title: Remakes Are A Waste Of Time.....The Reboot!
text: What a waste of time. Why was this remade? It's hardly different at all from the 2004 version or whatever year that was. Okay taken on it's own, the film is okay. The villain is resolved peaceably at the end. And everyone lives. Like watching the A-Team here in 2022.But it was not necessary to remake. And they are already remaking it again so I hear.4/10.

title: You will like it.
text: My review will be short. I don't have so many things to say, because it's a great movie, and I only write big reviews for bad movies. I'm a huge Spider Man fan, and I liked the other 3 movies of the franchise. Now, lets just face it: New story, new actors. Andrew Garfield is really good, and Emma Stone is adorable. Is the hero that we wanted to see, the hardcore hero of the comics. He's still nerd, but he is cool, funny and kinda hipster. You will not regret. You really like the Spider Man franchise ? You will like it cause the story is awesome and the actors are good. You're not? Watch in 3D, and enjoy the visual effects.

title: In many ways superior to Sam Raimi's "Spider-Man"
text: The last Spider-Man movie was 5 years ago, and here we are at a reboot? Who cares! Marc Webb's (his name suggests that this film was his destiny, no?) "The Amazing Spider-Man" has enough freshness in it to make this latest blockbuster worth the watch. Although Spidey's origin tale is basically the same, Webb takes more time here than his predecessor to develop the characters and establish more motivation for the story to take place. Acted with gusto by the likes of Rhys Ifans, Sally Field, Denis Leary and Martin Sheen, especially notable are the performances of Andrew Garfield as Peter Parker/Your Friendly Neighborhood Spider-Man and Emma Stone as his sweetheart Gwen Stacey, a resourceful firecracker who can take care of herself if need be. The chemistry between the two leads will stick to your heart like a whole web-ball of warmth and charisma. The nuances that all of the actors bring to their characters ring of such truth that we are swept up into the fantastic elements of the story as easily as Parker swings from web to web. Most surprisingly, the RomCom based Webb directs the action superbly, using 3D well and staging everything where we can see and understand what's going on, making the battles all the more exciting and intense. And what a villain he's brought to the screen in The Lizard, Dr. Curt Conners' biologically created alter-ego. He's brutally strong, exceptionally fast, and still has his wits about him even when he's all scaled out! For all of the feelings of sameness and repetitiveness, this "Spider-Man" earns its name. It's nothing short ofAmazing! And on a closing note, I was surprised to see that this film was shot digitally, on a RED camera. I would be lying if I said that this film didn't look great, and you could have fooled me. I suppose if Marty Scorsese is ready to embrace digital, then I can at least acknowledge that digital film-making may finally be getting somewhere respectable. (sighs) -Thomas Bond, TheFilmDiscussion.com

title: True to its roots- A Super Hero Comic Book Movie
text: Almost as if lifted out of Amazing Fantasy #15 . Some scenes were right out of Stan Lees original version and Spiderman looked like John Buscmea drew him...Peter Parker looked like Peter Parker...There was a story and not just a SFX-CFX slug fest. Spiderman wise cracked . The movie was like reading a few issues of Spiderman ...penned by Stan and drawn by John Buscema. Of course some of the elements are missing: The Daily Bugle and J. Jonah Jameson. the Wrestling fight... but then those elements have been covered by the first installments. But overall this is one of the best Comic Book movies (true to the Comic Book roots) I have seen. This Spiderman and more so this Peter Parker is how I always imagined these Characters. I am a Comic book fan since the late 60ties and have not missed a single Spider Man comic since then and to me the original stories penned by Stan are still the best. The movie strikes a nice balance between action and story.

title: It could have been worse...try harder next time!
text: Memo to the producers of "The Amazing Spiderman": 1)There's a reason they're called comic books. They may not be funny but at least they're a lot of fun. Unlike this movie adaptation. 2)Being tongue-tied and sex appeal are not synonymous. Sputtering, stuttering and stammering does not make you irresistible to women. Even if you're Spiderman's altar ego, Peter Parker. 3)If the hero of the movie inadvertently maims a half-dozen people in a subway car before he realizes his incredible powers, he's a pretty crappy hero. 4) While crafting a script, the screenwriters should check on what they wrote before. Which might explain why tiny lizards are heading for the sewers and what happened to the killer with the star on his hand. 5) Oscar Wilde loved incredible coincidences. But this isn't a farce. So maybe the fact that the kid who gets bitten by a bio-genetically engineered spider is dating the daughter of the cop who is chasing the masked avenger is just a bit too much deus ex machina. 6)When Peter Parker soars across a basketball court and wrecks the backboard, isn't a medical exam a better idea than detention? 7)Just because a director is named Webb doesn't mean that he's the logical candidate for a Spiderman movie. Or didn't you know he spelled it with two b's? 8) You made one terrific decision. Martin Sheen gives his customary fine performance as Spiderman's Uncle Ben. But don't let it go to your heads.

title: Peter Parker's Story - Well Told.
text: The Amazing Spider-Man has received far too many mixed and bad reviews from people angry that the beloved previous series was rebooted so quickly. To put it simply, the cinematography, plot, acting and character development of The Amazing Spider-Man make 2002's Spider-Man look like a bad TV Show that has lost most of its connection to its original source material. Many people claiming to be comic book fans are complaining about vast and sweeping inaccuracies from the comics, and are raging about how Stan Lee should be furious and "This isn't Spider-Man, it's Twilight!"Now, this film doesn't exactly follow the comic book down to the page, there are a few slight changes that I won't point out for the sake of avoiding spoilers. However compared to most comic book movies, this film is very surprisingly accurate, and far more so than its predecessors. Very few actual Spider-Man fans have any complains about the romantic scenes between Gwen and Peter (although we're used to reading about them in college, they make the transition to high school very well), and love the way classic characters like the Lizard and Captain Stacy have been modernized while remaining true to the original spirit of their creators. Certainly this Peter Parker is a far more modern high school student than the old one (who was in high school for around forty minutes), but this needs to happen! It's not 1967, and we need characters who are relatable NOW. This Peter Parker is a superb modernization of the original character and captures the Peter Parker/Spider-Man magic much better than the previous movie version.There is room for criticism in my review however, and some complaints are well founded. For example, complaints that the film was not well paced do have some merit. It's almost as though the Peter Parker scenes are slow and thoughtful, but the Spider-Man scenes are rushed and panicked. Unfortunately to anyone disappointed, Spider-Man has always been about Peter Parker, and we've seen three movies of him swinging around and hitting villains while rescuing damsels in distress. Now it's time for Peter Parker's story.

title: Webb ftw!
text: This movie will probably surprise a lot of people who were obviously scorned by Spiderman 3. granted, this new take has nothing to do with the past series. at a pretty moderate pace, Spiderman doesn't dwell too long on the origin we alllll know too well but it does put a slightly more in-depth look at how things came to be. the story line is solid though there are times where it seems as if some scenes were skipped or rushed, the action needless to say was "amazing". very creative uses of web-slinging throughout and clear shots of the battles made for a great treat. its pretty clear why the sequel was already greenlit well before this even dropped. all should enjoy the ride, if not for the action itself then for the on-screen chemistry brought well by Stone and Garfield.

title: The Amazing Spider-Man (3D) (U/A)---------------Rating: 4/5
text: The Amazing Spider-Man (3D) (U/A)---------------Rating: 4/5It is an action superhero flick...... Amazing 3D effects especially in the climax...... Stunts and BGM was amazing...... New Direction and cast of this spider man was amazing.....Catch the spiderman in 3D to enjoy more.......Peter Parker finds a clue that might help him understand why his parents disappeared when he was young. His path puts him on a collision course with Dr. Curt Connors, his father's former partner.While walking down the aisles after the end credits started rolling for 'The Amazing Spider-Man', I overheard a couple discussing about the film. While the boy argued that there wasn't anything new in the film and was 'just' about Spidey jumping all over the city, the girl -who seemed to have been reasonably entertained - shot back stating -'What else did you expect?'.Well, this argument pretty much seals the word of mouth that the film is all set to get. For those expecting Spiderman in all the swinging action, they would indeed have some good time for those two hours. However for those expecting something indeed new, then well, 'The Amazing Spider-Man' isn't quite the film for them.

title: Better Than the Sam Raimi Movies Even!
text: The Amazing Spider-Man is a reboot of the Spider-Man movie franchise. It's mostly the same story of Peter Parker, a high school nerd, who gets bitten by a genetically enhanced spider and gains super-reflexes, strength and the ability to climb on anything. He develops a web- shooting device and becomes the amazing Spider-Man.I am a huge fan of the Sam Raimi Spider-Man movies. His interpretation is just brilliant. The first movie is a bit outdated today, but it is still a fun action movie. The second movie took it to a whole new level, and we actually cared more about Peter Parker than Spider-Man, but that was also because Spidey only had about 30 - 40 minutes of screen-time throughout the entire movie. And finally the third movie, which is my favorite, balanced the screen-time of Parker and Spidey, while also having some of the best superhero action of all time, and some of most emotional scenes in superhero movies to date. So with a superhero trilogy this good, of course I was skeptical about a reboot. Especially since it's only been 5 years since Spider-Man 3, and because originally it was supposed to be Spider-Man 4, but it got canceled and turned into a reboot instead. I just didn't see how a brand new Spider-Man movie starting from scratch could top anything like the Sam Raimi trilogy. But I was wrong.The Amazing Spider-Man is the best Spider-Man movie to-date! And that's saying a lot. Even if this movie doesn't have the charm of the first and second movie, and the emotion and action of the third movie, it still somehow manages to be more enjoyable. Or at least better.It's very hard to explain how The Amazing Spider-Man is better than Spider-Man 3, but it has to be because the characters are introduced better than they were in the first Sam Raimi movie. In the first Sam Raimi movie, we didn't really get to know any of the characters too well. It wasn't until the second movie came along that we finally hit home with Peter Parker, Mary Jane Watson, Aunt May and all these wonderful characters. But with this start of a new trilogy, it's done much better. With Sam Raimi's movies, it wasn't until the third movie that I cared enough about the characters to almost tear up in some of the scenes. But in the new movie, however, I was very touched by what happened to the characters, even if this is the first time I've been introduced to them. The main character is much more relatable, because he isn't as awkward as the Tobey Maguire Peter, who didn't really even out until the second movie. The only character who they didn't improve on was Aunt May. Rosemary Harris as Aunt May in the Sam Raimi trilogy has to be one of the best characters, as she led some of the most emotionally powerful scenes in those movies. In The Amazing Spider-Man one, she is younger and not as warm-hearted. But of course, the same went for Aunt May in the first Sam Raimi movie, and then she became your favorite relief character in the second movie.There is so much to talk about when it comes to the characters in The Amazing Spider-Man, because nearly all of them are so fleshed-out and improved from the Sam Raimi movies, even though it's only the first movie in the now on-going trilogy. The last character I wanna talk about is the new villain: Lizard. Dr. Connors was a character in the Sam Raimi movies. He didn't have much screen-time in the second movie, but was there none-the-less. It wasn't until the third movie where he actually had a relevance to the plot, where he explained to Peter what the symbiot was. But in this one, he turns into Lizard. He is very similar to Dr. Octopus in Spider-Man 2: He is working on a ground-breaking invention, but it's not ready for testing. He testes it on himself, crap goes wrong, he turns mad and decides to harness the potential of his invention and take it out on the entire city of New York. See, just like Doc Oc. The only significant difference is that he is not as over-confident about testing his creation as Octopus is. Anyways, I really liked this villain, and he was better than Green Goblin from the first movie. He was just as good as Dr. Octopus, but personally not as good as Sandman or Venom. Sure, more developed, but not as enjoyable to watch.As I think I mildly stated, the story is much better. It's much more well-paced and interesting. And the action and special effects are MUCH better! Let's face it, the original Spider-Man looks like crap now-a-days, and this new movie makes even the second and third movies look bad in comparison! Some of the action is so intense and exciting, that I was on the edge of my seat many times! The scene on the bridge is just so spectacularly suspenseful. I love it!As a Spider-Man movie to start a new trilogy, The Amazing Spider-Man is incredible, and makes the first Sam Raimi movie look like a high school project (granted a very good high school project, but still). And as a Spider-Man movie, it's also very, very good! Some people complain that this movie was just made so that Sony could claim their rights to the character of Spider-Man, but since the movie turned out to be this good, I don't see how that's a problem. The Amazing Spider-Man is an awesome movie! While it may not have the charm of the Sam Raimi movies, and it may be a bit too long, it succeeds on everything else and I can't wait to see the sequels.P.S: Bring Venom and Dr. Octopus back for one of the sequels, please!

title: Sticky Fingers
text: I wonder had the director's name not been Webb, would life had led him to directing a Spider-Man movie....Anyways, Funny that stealing is central to the story in "The Amazing Spider-Man," from Peter Parker assuming someone else's identity to burglarize a lab, to his complicity in a convenience store theft, or someone attempting to steal his father's work in the opening sequence only for Peter to later pass that work off as his own. It's funny because the movie is largely a lazy retread of the same notes hit upon in the last Spider-Man series, which had only wrapped up with its third installment half a decade ago when this was released. The major exception preventing me from ranking this lower is that there's improvement in the camerawork.As in "Spider-Man" (2002), the superhero saves some people while fighting a green villain on a bridge. Again, Parker has a personal connection with that man-turned-monster, both of whom have at least one or two scenes where they seem to be insanely talking to themselves in their mind. Despite a protagonist who is a photographer and swings between skyscrapers, the camerawork for both movies is largely disappointingly rudimentary. The reboot's ending is actually an exception, as the digital camera finally starts flying through the air along with Spidey. Parker's picture taking, however, hardly figures into this version at all--at least not in any interesting way. His newfound fascination with skateboarding and, evidently, hair products receive more attention. The movie itself is photographically darker, which may help to conceal some of the CGI, such as of the talking lizard, that already seems somewhat dated, or maybe it's just another pastiche of "The Dark Knight" (2008).Another scene here seems as though it were a direct quotation of the 2002 picture, where Spidey goes down an eerily familiar-looking alley (stylistically, that is) to save a woman from being harassed by men. In the 2002 version, this was actually a well-made scene, as far as tropes of a hero rescuing a damsel from a rape attempt go, culminating in that famous upside-down kiss. Not here. Another thing I don't like in this iteration is that Spidey's web slinging is a mechanical invention rather than a natural growth of the mutant spider. That made for a perverse puberty metaphor regarding the teenage superhero when you think about it. Andrew Garfield's character, on the other hand, besides stealing, also has sticky fingers for grabbing women--ripping the blouse off a subway passenger and, later, pulling and twirling Emma Stone in by the hip for a rooftop smooch.The Uncle Ben stuff is so familiar, I guess, that it seems as though the editors tried to rush through it, which kind of reminds me of a similar treatment of Bruce Wayne's parents in "Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016). Neither works well. They also cast Sally Field as Aunt May and, then, give her nothing to work with. And the construction crew plotline and music for the finale are hokey. Indeed, a lot of "The Amazing Spider-Man" merely feels perfunctory. Not a movie made because anyone had a novel interpretation of the familiar comic-book series, but rather to satisfy Sony's demand to keep vomiting out Spidey movies every few years so as to keep their rights to the franchise so that they can keep vomiting. It's a vicious circle. The sequel turned out so bad they had to make a deal with Disney's Marvel Cinematic Universe to keep their Spidey from being stolen. I don't get why this first one did fairly well with critics and audiences. Dennis Leary's police captain's hint of a Spider-Man v Godzilla flick sounds, well, if not better, than at least more ridiculously amusing to me than this popcorn fodder.

title: Spiderman is back! A must see film.
text: This film is really great. It made me like Spiderman again after the disgrace of the other Spiderman movies. This new launch of Spiderman really holds true to the the Amazing Spiderman comic books which makes for a great film. Andrew Garfield is also a great Spiderman, he is not dorky like Tobey Maguire and fits the Spiderman character perfectly. Emma Stone is also brilliant as Gwen Stacy. The movie does contain a lot of CGI but again it is a superhero movie so it wouldn't be possible without CGI. However unlike most other movies the CGI in this film is perfect. It really makes you feel like the characters are real. Definitely a must see!

title: A Delightful Web
text: I was slightly hesitant to watch the Amazing Spiderman, having grown up with the idea that Tobey Maguire was the boy wonder. I was happily surprised, however, that I spent the money and time with a Spiderman for a new generation. Some argue that not enough time has passed between the Amazing Spiderman and Spiderman 3 (which I thought was awful), but I beg to differ. At the rate at which information travels, how social networking shapes the daily lives of all around the world, and when CGI changes the way we watch film, a Spiderman for 2012 is a welcomed addition to Marvel.While the story is similar to that of Spiderman 1- the story is based upon the comic book tale of Peter Parker for crying out-loud and so will be the same- I found that what made the Amazing Spiderman amazing was the fresh, tender face of Andrew Garfield. It may seem strange to think of Spiderman as tender, but above anything else this movie offers- action, love, revenge, responsibility- it offers a reality check for all those out there who think that being a superhuman offers the best of both worlds. Garfield makes Spiderman more than a mask, more than a super-human who fights for what is right. Garfield as Spiderman struggles to find his way and demonstrates that it is not always easy to find the right path and stay on it. Life, ultimately will get in the way of whatever and whoever you decide to be and how the Amazing Spiderman deals with living a life of secrets and power, is what makes this film soar.There are a few cheese-filled scenes that slowed the film down, but overall they did not alter the theme of the movie. Emma Stone was brilliant, as always and casting her alongside Garfield was simply one of the best matches I have seen in a long time. Rhys Ifans was a likable villain, which is something that must happen in superhero films these days. No longer is being bad 'just because' a characterization, the villain (whether Voldemort or even the Joker from the Dark Knight) has to have justification for being evil because just as being good is defined by choices, so is being bad.Ifans seeks to be change who he is and uses science as the way to reach his goal. His experiment backfires and he is left changed in more ways than one and the last half of the film focuses on the results of mixing unknown science with human desire. Throughout the Amazing Spiderman is this idea that wanting something and changing who you are do not always yield greatness. Peter Paker struggles with his new identity and powers, just as Dr.Curt Conners must accept his fate. The interaction between the two characters is, in the beginning genuine and so it makes the fallout from their alter-egos all the more interesting. The struggle of whether or not being different is a blessing or a curse is flushed out, as well as the loneliness that often follows the cost of greatness. The CGI and music are acceptable, a misplaced Coldplay song through me off a little, but I like any movie that plays the Shins. The action scenes with the instrumentals was lacking, loud piano cords do not a scene suspenseful. If the future of superhero films is telling the tale of why superheros are not so different from the rest of us, the future of superheros is bright indeed.

title: outstanding
text: The movie was so amazing, except for one thing which is the events were so fast happening. All in all it was worth it and I advice you to go and watch it. if I want to compare it to the original spiderman movie, I'll chose this one. Simply because it's giving the store in a Specified way that make you understand better how all it happened. I was waiting for this movie about a year, let say I was expecting more than what i saw but, I didn't say It isn't a good movie. It's really excellent. i'm hoping the next part will be something spectacular like what happened with the dark night ! However i'm gonna give it 10 of 10 because I like spader guy ;)

title: The Amazing Spiderman..Worth the wait. Worth the excitement.
text: Right, so I have been anxiously waiting for the release of this movie since the first trailer hit the internet. Being a Spidey fan since I was about 4, The idea of a new Spiderman movie after 5 long years of waiting since the last one in 2007 (Spiderman) made me quite happy. After just watching the movie I can safely say that it in my mind it beats it's prequels in every aspect. The story dwells into the life of an average teenager Peter Parker who is keen on unsolving the mystery of his parents disappearance, which if you recall was never mentioned in the Spiderman trilogy of 2002 (correct me if I'm wrong). This leads to the introduction of Dr. Connors played by Rhys Ifans as a colleague of Peter Parker's father. The character is portrayed brilliantly by Rhys and probably made the movie worthwhile. Emma Stone, who inherits the role of Gwen Stacy does a much better job than Kirsten Dunst (Mary Jane) at being the love interest of Parker. However the only drawback for me in this movie would have to be the fact that there was in my mind a lack of Spiderman scenes, overshadowed by Peter Parker and Gwen Stacy in conversation. While enjoyable,a few more action scenes would have done it justice. But I definitely enjoyed this movie and would not mind watching it a second time while it stays in cinemas.

title: The Amazing Spider-Man was a great movie.
text: The Amazing Spider-Man was an amazing movie because of the actors and actresses, Andrew Garfield played a really great role as being Spider-Man and Emma Stone played a great role by being by Spider-Man's side and helping him when he needed it the most. They both really helped each other in the movie. And I think they are an excellent pair to work with. If you are someone who really likes and enjoys Spider-Man movies you know there is always a villain, The villain in the movie is fantastic, the visual effects that the directors and producers use to make the villain really make it seem real. In some movies I see the visual effects of a villain or a monster seem fake to me, but in The Amazing Spider-Man it definitely seems real.I am only 14 years old and I really like Spider-Man movies.

title: Incredible in all genres. Great action, romance, drama, and effects.
text: the original Spiderman series really set the bar for superhero movies. Some people say the dark knight raised it. The Amazing Spiderman rips the bar off and ate it for breakfast. The movie is unbelievably fantastic from start to finish. The setups are not distracting, but not overlooked either. They tie in to later events, and really pull you into the story. There is never a dull moment, with action, suspense, romance, or breathtaking visual images in every scene. I went to the theater expecting a decent flick, one that might think of rivaling the original, as a nice set-up to the dark night rises in a few weeks. My mind was completely blown, and now I'm wondering if batman better watch his back. The Dark Knight really changed the way people looked at superheros, and The Avengers further cemented that belief, but The Amazing Spiderman proves that it can definitely contest those two. The Dark Knight Rises better watch its back, because The Amazing Spiderman takes viewers for an exciting ride, and believe it or not, really has a chance of being the blockbuster of the summer.

title: Really great movie!
text: I absolutely loved this movie! Every actor and actress in this movie did a really great job. Andrew Garfield makes a great Spider Man and Emma Stone does a great job as Gwen Stacy. Rhys Ifans was good as the Lizard and as Dr. Connors. Sally Field, Denis Leary, and Martin Sheen all played very well in their roles. The Amazing Spider Man makes the first three look even worse than I thought they were before. I loved almost everything about this movie. There's only one thing that I didn't love about it. They made the origin story very long. It was a pretty long movie because of this, but everything was very enjoyable. Everything in the movie contributed to the overall story. I think anyone would love this movie. I love comic books and comic movies and most action movies. I took my girlfriend who only likes comedy and horror movies and she enjoyed most of this movie which I wasn't expecting. So if you want to go see a really fun, exciting movie with a good story and good action, go see The Amazing Spider Man. It's definitely worth it!

title: Marc Webb takes us back to The Amazing Spider-Man's basics.
text: Actually I loved it! I think that Marc Webb, the film director, did an excellent job by getting us closer to Peter Parker, He perfectly captured the adolescent presented in the comics. He did great by taking us to the basic principles of Spider-Man presented in the comics, a young man with human conflicts like anyone.Definitely not a pure action film, Marc Webb takes time to develop the characters and I think it succeeds very well. Although for children may seem a little slow.Andrew Garfield and Emma Stone definitely an asset to the film, I liked more the aunt & uncle cast in this movie than in the last trilogy. The whole cast in general is great.The only thing that didn't convinced me was the Lizard face, it looks more human than lizard, but I prefer this design thousand times to the Green Goblin's costume in Spider-Man 1 which had nothing to do with any outfit presented in the comics.I don' t know if Marc Webb plans to show Gwen Stacy- Green Goblin's storyline in the next films, would be very interesting to see the response of the general audience who aren't familiarized to that comic storyline. I found the 3D IMAX brutal and 100% recommended.In short, I think a superhero movie very well made, different rhythm to the Avengers, but more than justified and definitely the best of Spider-Man.

title: One of the best movie I have ever seen!!!
text: Seriously, this movie is groundbreaking, better than what I expected, anyone who says this is bad is lying, because do not accept such a change of mind (from hate to love)I still love Sam Raimi trilogy (yes...TRILOGY)and I think Spider-Man 1 is the best Spider-Man of them, but compared to TASM, that movie transforms itself in a Green Lantern of life, almost everything in the reboot is better, The Acting, the CGI, the action scenes, Spider-Man 1 only wins in the soundtrack, both are great but the 2002 soundtrack is more captivating and emotional (which I like)The humor in this movie is just good, not hilarious but good, and that's a big change in the Spider-Man movies, the sarcastic Spider-Man that I always loved is finally here, but it really has to be improved in TASM 2, cause...you know, we all wanna laugh hard.The Story of this movie...is not untold, I mean the "Untold Story" that is why this reboot exist...doesn't exist, it is cutted off the movie, I really want to see Sony explaining why they may have cutted like 40 minutes of the movie, to make it a bad thing, I have a REALLY HIGH feeling that this movie could have been A LOT better if not so many scenes were cutted...I'm sad, man :(. But that doesn't make the movie bad at all.Anyway, the theaters should charge more for this movie, like U$30,00, because it is AWESOME, worth price, go watch it10/10

title: The worst first Spider-Man movie, but still alright.
text: This film has an entirely different feel from the other Spider-Man movies. I've heard complaints about this take on Spidey, and while I don't think he's the best I don't mind this different take on Peter. He definitely gives off 2000s skater vibes, but is also still an awkward teenager who's just trying to get the girl and do what's right.I don't think this movie holds a candle to the Raimi movies in terms of casting accuracy in looks or portrayal. It seems like they casted a lot of actors just off of popularity. However Andrew Garfield and Emma Stone both have amazing performances.While it's not necessarily better, the new futuristic take on Peter including the father thing is refreshing. Having his father tied to Dr. Connors and Oscorp is interesting but is left unresolved sadly.The Uncle Ben death isn't as memorable as in Raimi's Spider-Man, but it's still emotional. All the emotional scenes are really carried by Andrew's performances. All the way up to the ending battle with that amazing score.Dr. Connors' goal to help disabled people with the cross-genetic experiments is actually really interesting and I felt like I understood him. I was very invested in his character up until his first time becoming The Lizard and his turn to insanity. At that point he was just another crazy villain and all the people he gassed becoming reptile-like was kinda weird, but it is a comic book movie after all.One thing I do have to praise this movie for is the action scenes. The cinematography on Spider-Man's web-swinging is amazing and create some of the most memorable scenes in the film.However I didn't like how worked up Spidey was for half the film. I get it was because of his uncle dying, it's just not the type of Spider-Man I like to see or root for.Still this time I actually didn't mind the more melancholy ending. Definitely made you want to see where Peter's story would go in the eventual sequel.Overall not the best movie but not the worst.

title: amazing is only one word to describe this movie
text: after watching all 4 of the spider-man titled movies over the past decade Marc Webb's the amazing spider-man is by far the best yet with a new cast put into past roles and past characters put into different positions this adaptation is spot on instead of just placing Gwen Stacy in the middle of a series like spider-man three Emma stones character has finally developed a back story and ties in great compared with its comic book predecessor.and Andrew Garfield fits his role perfectly as he is a quit nerdy kid by day a like the comics a sometimes obnoxious and cocky to his enemies vigilante by night. Although there just a couple of scenes which leave you thinking what was the point of all that and leave some groaning but if you are a long time comic fan then this is a must see with the Dark knight Rises release getting closer i would see it fast as the hype will die down come July 20th to conclude the amazing spider-man is a must see for one reason AMAZING STORY and no random character drop ins and also Martin sheen

title: Emotional Depth and Brilliant Entertainment
text: I saw this today for the first time and I absolutely loved this film. I grew up with the comics and hand on heart, I can honestly say that this is a truly great film (for both geeks and regular cinema goers!) and one that is far more faithful to the Spidey universe than Raimi's version ever was. Sure, Raimi's was more accurate with the origin story, but when it comes to characters, this one has it spot on and is the comic come to life. Webb's new version manages to be both exciting and truly affecting. It has an emotional depth unlike a lot of similar genre films and is really quite an adult take on Spider-Man. It wisely takes the time to establish the characters and by the time the action starts, you're truly invested and care about the story and Peter. I'll be honest with you, the villain could have been better (although Rhys is great as Connors) and like Raimi's goblin design, could have done with a little bit more thought, and yes a giant lizard running around New York does jar with the new 'realism' aspect Webb has introduced, but these are minor quibbles when the overall package really is fantastic. Anyone going to see this just to see CGI fights (yes Michael Bay fans, I'm talking to you!) will likely be disappointed. But if you favour character and acting over spectacle (although it does have some fantastic effects and set pieces) this is for you. To give you and an example of the type of film this is, both the Guardian and Radio 4 gave this 4 out of 5 stars. Thats unheard of for a film like this!! I can't wait for the sequel. Bring it on!

title: Loved it
text: This movie was so good. I watched the original ones and really didn't like them. This movie used a cool actor to play a nerd while the previous ones used a nerd to play a nerd. This movie had INTENSE action. The acting was terrific and the actors were terrific. You can tell right off that the guy who played spider man will be a star in many up coming movies.The drama scenes were powerful and made me remember the times in my life when I experienced loss like they do, or love or whatever. Well done.My wife is a chic-flic lover and she enjoyed this as well. When the first spider man came out I was sooo stoked cause I read all the comics as a kid. I was let down. This version completely met my expectations.Total summary: loved it.

title: What has become of you spidey?
text: Watched it, and it is in my opinion the worst Spider-Man movie there is. The movie is more focused on the emotional relationship between Peter Parker and Gwen Stacy, there is not enough action it's all boring conversations and feelings.The actors looks way to old to be in high school. They also got Dr. Connors character all wrong, Connors wanted to maintain his human nature in the comic books, he didn't want to play a god. This Connors was very gloomy. Personally I think Andrew Garfield is a bad choice for Spider-Man, he looks like something that escaped Twilight, he doesn't look anything like a nerdy outcast.In the movie nothing about Peter's parents is really unveiled. I was looking forward to see the movie, I thought it was an interesting reboot, I liked the new costume and that they have gone back to the web shooters. But it was a great disappointment, I was hoping the Lizard could safe this movie but the villain was poorly made and nothing like I had expected.To me the best Spider-Man is and always will be Tobey Maguire.

title: I did not think it was possible
text: I really did not think that this reboot of Spiderman would be better then 2002's by Sam Rami. I was very pleasantly surprised. The weakest part of the 2002 movie was the cast, and especially Kristen Dunst. This was a great movie. The cast was spot on. The chemistry between Emma Stone and Andrew Garfield was terrific. The story was great and had a good balance for a superhero movie of action and dialog. There are a few weak points but after all it is a comic book. This was not related in any way to the origin story told in 2002, but for fans of Spiderman this version stays true to the essence that we know and love. Marvel has been on fire recently. They are doing a great job translating their stories to the big screen and this was no exception. I look forward to the next chapter.

title: The Amazing Spiderman - It's pretty, well, amazing!
text: The Amazing Spiderman is something special in the universe of comic book/superhero movies. They all feature the big, flashy CGI action sequences that make us ooh and aah. Some manage to make you care about the events on the screen, but not all of them manage to make you care about the characters and their motivations. Occasionally there is a compelling villain whose evil ways are logical. Even more rare is the love story that is equal parts sweet and believable. The Amazing Spiderman manages to be all of this, and then some.Peter Parker has had a rough time in his life. His parents inexplicably abandon him at his aunt and uncles one night when he's a child, and the mystery of their disappearance still haunts him. He's a bit of a social outcast at school, and he is picked on pretty mercilessly as a result. He's also got a crush on Gwen Stacy, but never has the guts to say anything to her about it. But a trip to the Oscorp building while searching for answers to his parent's disappearance is about to change Peter's life forever.While this is both a remake and a reboot for the franchise, rest assured that the cast and direction breathe new life into this familiar story. Marc Webb's direction is skillful and patient, and never rushes through the quiet moments that really inform who these people are. The result is a cast of characters that are very real and act on real emotions. As much as these movies are about the spectacle, they also have to exist within the boundaries of a human story. This is what gives superhero stories resonance and meaning, and Webb makes his time count.When Webb isn't actually telling a story within a superhero movie, he's setting up some impressive action sequences. One where Spiderman is rescuing a boy from a car that has fallen off a bridge is particularly breathtaking. The POV moments while swinging through the city are pretty cool, albeit a little unnecessary. Webb also uses the hero's abilities in some new and intriguing ways that I won't spoil.I was excited from day one to hear that Andrew Garfield was chosen to play Peter/Spiderman, and he never once disappoints here. He's appropriately vulnerable and sarcastic without the mask, and overly confident when shrouded in his anonymity. Emma Stone also does an excellent job as his love interest, Gwen. Their chemistry is palpable, and their moments on screen are very natural. Rhys Ifans as Dr. Connors/The Lizard does a decent enough job as the villain. The character is written well, and he makes a more than adequate first test for Spiderman. It's easy to empathize with his mad scientist ways given his predicament, at least before he goes insane with power that is. Rounding out the cast are Denis Leary as Captain Stacy, who happens to be Gwen's father, and Sally Field and Martin Sheen are charming as always as Aunt May and Uncle Ben.Given the original series is only about 10 years old, it seemed like an odd idea at first that Columbia Pictures would seek to reboot their franchise. From what I understand it had to do with the studio maintaining the character rights from being bought out, but the story changes depending on what you read. And despite the fair number of hiccups in part 3, Raimi's trilogy is still a great addition to the superhero movie lexicon. The Amazing Spiderman doesn't have as many problems as part 3, but what's there is pretty noticeable because of how good the rest of the movie is. The design of the lizard leaves something to be desired, the promises of the "untold story" of Spiderman being told in the trailers is largely a lie, and the movie itself features some pretty glaring plot holes. But by the end of the movie I didn't really care. Garfield and Stone's performances are miles above those of Tobey Maguire and Kirsten Dunst, and I was completely invested in their romance rather than laughing at it. The action is thrilling and emotionally driven without being contrived, and the visuals are top notch. The Amazing Spiderman is above average summer fare, and sets up some fun territory to be explored in the sequels to come.Follow me on Twitter @Mrhuffsmyfather http://about.me/cory.huff3897

title: Watch and Enjoy
text: Hands Down this was a good movie to just simply watch and enjoy. Not necessary to watch in 3-D... As a movie lover be prepared for a slow start, but as a comic book reader would know it is a "origin story," but nevertheless hang in there for the good stuff, it pays off. Also, Okay... if your too caught up in "Raimi's Smell of Flatulence" by all means watch this movie and do your best to hate it, But Watch it. Compared and Contrasted: Way Better than the Fiasco Known as SPIDERMAN 3, Gotta Wait for part 2 to compare it and so yet Like Spiderman (2002), this movie holds it own!!! Can't wait for the Trinity soon to come. OVERALL: Action level was enough to satisfy, Dramatic impression was enough to tear-jerk me a few times, Comedic essence made me laugh a few times, Romance was enough and not too overwhelming (Love that Emma Stone By the way) and the Suspense was fantastic. So I give this movie a 10 for its enjoyment factor. Go Watch and Enjoy

title: Andrew Garfield's performance helps TAS to another level
text: First of all I wasn't happy that Sony was going to reboot the series. But an the other hand I was relieved. The movies were great, but something wasn't right about the last spider-movies. And it was the touch that Marc Webb brought into this movie. With Webb you could character development. The characters were better developed than Raimi's characters. Especially Peter Parker and Gwen Stacy. Peter Parker was perfectly played by Andrew. No hate against McGuire. Absolutely not. But Garfield's Parker was funnier, smarter and he wasn't goofy. The level of the movie wasn't better than The Dark Knight, but it wasn't worse than the stupid F4-movies. It was certainly better than the Raimi's trilogy. The movie had a good connection with the comics and the very first love interest: Gwen Stacy. So if you're a spider-fan, go to the movie and for the not die-hard spider fans, go see the movie too.

title: Better than Spiderman 3, not as good as Spiderman 2, on par with Spiderman
text: The story of this superhero movie is that Peter Parker is struggling in his life. He's the punching bag for Flash, the bully at school, and he's trying to figure out why his parents left him so many years ago. After he gets bitten by a spider (go figure), he starts to develop powers, which puts him on a collision course with Dr. Curt Conners' alter ego, the Lizard.First off, let me say that this movie is a huge step up from Spiderman 3. I know that this is a reboot and really isn't a part of the Sam Raimi trilogy, but let me tell you that this movie is on par with the one from 2002. That's how good it is.Next, I'm going to say that it's about time that we had the Lizard as the villain. We've already seen two films where Dr. Connors plays a supporting role, so it's great to see him as a main character to the movie, and Rhys Ifans plays him well.Speaking of Ifans, he, along with Garfield, Stone, Leary, Sheen, and Fields all deliver terrific performances. Sally Fields plays Aunt May, the protective Aunt who worries about Peter when he's out late. Then there's Martin Sheen as Uncle Ben, who provides many words of wisdom for Peter that really echo Peter's destiny as a hero. Emma Stone plays Gwen Stacy, the love interest of Peter/Spiderman, while her father is played by Dennis Leary, who is great as always. As mentioned above, Rhys Ifans is a great Lizard, but if anyone steals the show, it's obviously Andrew Garfield as Peter Parker/Spiderman. He seemed to be comfortable in balancing Peter the insecure nerd and Spiderman the loudmouthed crime-fighter, which is a good thing.Overall, a job well done to everyone. It doesn't quite hit the heights of Spiderman 2, but it is enough to say that the franchise has been rebooted and it's in safe hands. A 9/10 for me.

title: Makes the previous outings looks like Batman Returns, Batman Forever and Batman & Robin respectively
text: I wasn't expecting much from this movie based on the previous three Spider-man movies. I had been hoping for a reboot of the franchise ever since I had seen the first Spider-Man movie 10 years earlier.This movie gives us a Spider-Man that's much more true to the original comics. I wasn't at all surprised when Tobey Maguire's Spider-Man wasn't considered for inclusion in The Avengers. The previous three movies did nothing to boost his career, but I can expect to see a lot more from Andrew Garfield in the coming years and I would love to see him in the sequel to The Avengers. Emma Stone also manages to outshine Kirsten 'Dunce' as the love interest, but in all fairness, that's not terribly difficult for such a sub-par actress like Kirsten.Even if this story had been done before, it certainly hadn't been given the respectful treatment that it had in this film. The 3D is this movie could hardly have been done any better. The common denominator in all the bad reviews, besides the fact that they were apparently written by 12 year-olds (seriously, read some of them) is that people simply didn't like the villain, therefore they complain about the CGI to try to give themselves credibility.This is on track to be the movie of the year and not The Avengers.

title: what a let down
text: Sorry, but this movie was horrible compared to Toby Mcguire's first Spiderman. I loved that Spiderman movie; it was funny and had a great story. In this remake, it's not funny and everything in it has been seen before. And Andrew Garfield goes around with his hair sticking up and just wasn't good casting. The way Peter Parker finds out about his super powers was no where near as good. And this movie copy cats so much from the first, like having Ben die, how he designs the spidey suit, how he gets back at the bully at school. And all of it was done worse in this film than the first one.FINAL VERDICT: I'm so glad I waited till this was on cable so I didn't pay to watch it. I recommend watching the Toby Mcguire ones and staying away from this.

text: Well it is realistic as weird as that may sound, but it was pretty good actually, I didn't know how I would like Andrew Garfield as Spiderman, but he was great! Not as good as Toby though, Toby was the quintessential nerd for me. He's awesome in every movie he is in. Emma Stone was so much better than Kristen Dunst. title: Maguire was good enough, Garfield took it up a notch!
text: I never realised that Maguire was only decent, until I saw Garfield's superior acting, complexity, depth, and vulnerability.I'm not quite sure what stopped AG getting his trilogy but the "Amazing" two certainly seemed to have more to it in every way.I never realised that Maguire was only decent, until I saw Garfield's superior acting, complexity, depth, and vulnerability.(repeated below to qualify as a review, don't read)I'm not quite sure what stopped AG getting his trilogy but the "Amazing" two certainly seemed to have more to it in every way.I never realised that Maguire was only decent, until I saw Garfield's superior acting, complexity, depth, and vulnerability.I'm not quite sure what stopped AG getting his trilogy but the "Amazing" two certainly seemed to have more to it in every way.

title: "The Amazing Spider-Man"
text: I really appreciate Sam Raimi as a director, and I do really like his first two 'Spider-Man' movies, but the problem is that they stray so far from the comic books. And then after the mess that was 'Spider-Man 3,' I lost interest for the series. Now, five years later we have a reboot. Some argue it's too soon, and for a while I agreed, but then I started reading into it and watching the trailers and I began to be pumped.'The Amazing Spider-Man' is directed by Marc Webb, director of the Indie Romantic Comedy '(500) Days of Summer,' so the amount of romance in the film can be expected, but surprisingly it works well. Marc Webb does a masterful job directing this film, creating the dark tone that was set for comic book films in 2008's 'The Dark Knight.' The performances in the film are top notch. Andrew Garfield, 29, is very believable as a teenager, and Emma Stone is absolutely great as Gwen Stacey. Martin Sheen and Sally Fields are great as Uncle Ben and Aunt May, Rhys Ifans is a good villain, and Dennis Leary plays a tough police chief, Captain Stacey.The story telling is more intriguing than in 2002's 'Spider-Man,' mainly because we get back story and reasoning as to why Peter Parker does the things he does. This is a fantastic comic book movie, one of the best, and even though it doesn't quite meet the heights of 'The Avengers,' I really enjoyed it, and I think it is one of the best comic book films out there today.

title: The reboot no-one really wanted has been released. Check out the Film-Vault review!
text: A new Peter Parker is donning the red and blue spandex and taking on the mantle of Spiderman. Its Garfield Vs Maguire, Stone Vs Dunst and Webb Vs Raimi. Who will win?The Answer is Garfield, Stone and Webb. This film matches the tone of how I always perceived Spiderman, and the actors and director hit the mark again and again scene after scene. It is an origin story, so we get the familiar bits, Peter gets bitten by a radioactive spider, Uncle Ben gets killed yada yada yada, but because the human side of the story is so engrossing the superhero bits take you by surprise, even the ones you know are coming. It really had me going for a while that they weren't going to kill Uncle Ben in this movie.Brit Andrew Garfield is Spidey and my does he shine. In a (reaaallly) shoddy article I wrote for this website about two years ago, I commented on how Tobey Maguire's Spiderman was always whinging and whining. Garfield's Spiderman has the same problems, more so probably, but there is something about web-slinging through a city and outsmarting criminals that should put a smile on your face. That is where Webb shines. He has crafted the most realistic but still fantastic superhero story that I think has been told, by pumping it full of relatable human emotions. Enter Emma Stone as Gwen Stacey, and my is she fine. I can't remember an on-screen role haunting me as much as this one, aside from Zooey Deschanel in Webb's earlier work 500 Days of Summer. Not only is she beautiful, but she is kind, friendly, smart and brave. It's really quite a step above Kirsten Dunst's screaming bag of meat Mary-Jane. It's a perfect Emma Stone performance, and if it had been given in any film type other than super-hero, more people would be talking about it. She is given a lot to do, playing a turbulent emotional teenager has never been done so well. And the chemistry between them, really does sizzle.The villain, the Lizard. In my opinion, the design is a little off, but I can get over that. In human form Rhys Ifans is first class playing the slightly eccentric Curt Connors. However, if there is one true criticism of the film it's that Connors development seems rushed through all three acts, particularly in his relationship to Peter. They were supposed to be good friends but there connection seems weak and at times, forced. . Who else have we got? Oooh, The Illusive Man himself Martin Sheen playing Uncle Ben. It's a perfect bit of casting here, even if he is only in about two scenes, and managed to inexplicably pull the out-of-his-league Sally Field.From a directorial standpoint this is Marc Webb showing the world what he can do with a budget. He's pulled a fast one here, he has made a teenage rom-com but wrapped it in $300million dollars worth of special effects and spandex. Case and point, the discovery of his powers. As soon as he asks Gwen out, he feels all kinds of confident, and that really comes across, giving him the courage (cockiness?) to leap off buildings. Looking back at Raimi's Spiderman, it lacked this basic human connection and feels a little forced. Unfortunately, a couple of all too cheesy scenes occasionally snaps you out of the perfectly crafted realism, something I think could have been avoided.The music is truly awesome; blending the high octane stuff (but never over the top) with the lovey-dovey stuff and a bit of twinkly piano music for the lighter bits makes it the cleverest score of the year so far. The special effects are second to none and if there was a film that was designed for 3D it's this one - if you've been on the Spiderman ride at Universal studios you'll know what I mean. It feels like you're really there with him slinging through the city. The action, while good, isn't as good as Spiderman 2. Some of the Lizard fights are a lot of fun, but I can remember Spiderman fighting Doc Ock on the above ground Subway line and it still gives me goosebumps.While everyone was critical when this film was announced, I think they have all been silenced now. This film was everything a reboot should be, showing the original how it should have gone about it. With two perfectly cast leads (both with enormous futures) and a great director this is definitely not one to miss. Unfortunately this means that with a trilogy announced under the guidance of Sony, we won't see Spiderman in the Avengers for quite some time (but I sneakily liked this more, so I don't care).

title: A darker version of Spider-man !
text: I saw this movie in theaters last night and overall enjoyed it. You could wonder whats the point of rebooting a franchise only 10 years old, but when it delivers in the end, you won't hear me complain. First of, I liked the 3 previous Raimi movies, so with the new one coming so fast it's impossible not to compare them with each other. The first thing I noticed was the darker, more serious tone that was set from the beginning. It's like Marc Webb is going more in the direction of the new Batman movies, witch isn't a bad thing of course. Although I liked Tobey Maguire as Spider-man, I always thought he was a little to soft to play a hero. Andrew Garfield for me seems more fit for the role. He plays a more mature Peter Parker, which fits with the darker tone of the new movie. The special effects were also definitely the best of the series. However I felt that some key moments that makes Peter Parker become Spider-man, were a little bit rushed. It also left me open for some answers in the ending, but with probably a sequel coming the next years, they will be explained. There was some good humor in it to that had me laughing a couple of times. So overall: A darker tone, good humor, best CGI of the series, a good story with some minor flaws. There is really no reason for me to not like this movie. I would hold it on par with the first 2 Raimi movies. Looking forward to the future!

title: Why was it made?
text: Spider-man at this point is crawling in circles. The Amazing Spider-man makes no contribution to the Peter Parker continuum. There is nothing new or noteworthy about the 2012 Spidey. Instead of utilizing a fresh, innovative approach, Marc Webb and his writers replicate the formula drafted in the original film and redundantly make us witness the transformation of Peter Parker from outcast to superhero again. We saw this spiel only ten years ago. In comparison, see what Christopher Nolan envisioned for the Batman reboot: a realist, dark approach in stark contradiction to the Schumacher pluff. Here there is no appreciable difference between The Amazing Spider-man and the Sam Raimi trilogy. It's not a reboot; it's a recycle.And if you're going to recycle, then at least improve upon the original. It doesn't; its fatal sin is actual regression. The Maguire-Dunst combo was more dynamic and likably than Garfield-Stone – poor Emma was miserably miscast. In an era, where the audience is accustomed to dynamic heels, what we get is an over-sized CGI-ish lizard lacking all nuance and substance; a completely forgettable, default villain. It's not all bad though. The 3D aspect is one redeeming quality of the film especially in the latter scene where spidey is soaring through the rainy sky coming to the rescue. It's a fun moment.

title: Beginning of a new era
text: First of all let me tell you that this is not a complete story of "The amazing spider man". Its just the beginning. So you all need to be patient to know all your answers to the unsolved questions in the sequels.Coming to this movie, this is most probably the best explained story of peter parker right from the point the got super powers. This first part of the film focuses on Peter learning to use spider power. And we see early days of spider man wearing civil dresses with a mask.The second part focuses the major battle between the spider man and the antagonist. Best thing about the film is that they tell you a story of parker much elaborately which is not liked by the people who went to the hall to see spider man 4. Guys this is the beginning of a new story not just a new episode to the existing story.It has perfect emotions as the previous films lacked. The concern of *uncle and aunt for their nephew. *Loving couples *Father daughterThese emotions were very well shown.thats what makes this spider man movie a more matured one rather than just a fight between good and evil.As I told earlier its a incomplete story suggesting a much anticipated sequel.This is a very good movie to watch with family and friends and you'll have a great time. And remember..... Its not Spider Man 4. Its a new Series. Much better!

title: For once, the definitive Spider Man.
text: Andrew Garfield, the new Spidey, should have been the first Spider Man. The original, in this case the ubernerd Toby Maguire, was so terrible in the role that it beggared the imagination. And pairing up this dwarf with Kirsten Dunst, the statuesque love interest in the first go 'round, was about as believable as Michael Jackson's baby chimp mating with King Kong—a total and complete casting disaster—watching them kiss was like watching your parents make love. According to everything written about Stan Lee's original vision of this super hero, Peter Parker was much darker and more conflicted than the previous, watered down version, and it's about time that the producers got it right. Emma Stone was right for the role as the love interest as well, rounding out the superb cast. In short, this is the film that the first wanted to be.

title: Totally no reason of existence
text: I strongly believe that even people who did not have any special interest on Spiderman found the original Tobey Maguire trilogy at far more interesting than other superhero films. Why? Because simply these films (and especially 1st and 2nd) were very human-like, and especially moving! For example, who does not remember the original uncle-Ben scene?However, this new version of the spider man story is just too flat, and too poor compared to the original. Weak performances, poor storyline and definitely a movie without any social aspect or meaning. For me the only reason to watch this movie would be some action scenes, which however are not that impressive for 2012, and which render this film watchable for only a small minority. And I have to admit that the relatively high rating really surprises me.

title: Much More Enjoyable Than The Previous Films
text: The Amazing Spider-Man is a far superior film to any of the previous Sam Raimi Spider-man movies and it defies logic how anyone could like those movies over this. The action, the casting, the performances, the visuals...everything was so much better, and thankfully this version was MUCH less cheesy i.e. "You're the one who's out Gobby, out of your mind". I mean really?! The previous movies did have some decent comedic moments, but overall they were just mediocre action movies with decent CGI.This version however, is a film with much better action and has excellent CGI AND practical effects. This film used much more practical effects than the previous movies, so it's pretty funny to see people praising the Raimi films while calling this a "CGI crap-fest". The visuals are anything but crap and they interweave seamlessly with the live action scenes. Some of the action CGI from the previous films you could tell was CGI, but here you can't and if you say you can then you're talking rubbish. Some of the scripting may be a bit predictable, but no more predictable than what we've seen previously.Andrew Garfield as Peter Parker/Spider-man does an absolute bang up job and is the much better actor at playing these two roles than Tobey Maguire. Macguire did play a good "nerd" for Parker, but he was very two dimensional with his performances. Plus a jellyfish has more of a backbone than Maguire's Parker. I much preferred Garfield's version of Parker where he is seen more of a loner than a nerd and he captured this well in his performance. Even though she was playing a different character, Emma Stone as Gwen Stacy was far, far less annoying than Kirsten Dunst so that was a much added bonus. Sally Field, Martin Sheen, Denis Leary, and Rhys Ifans were all great in their individual roles as well, and the cameo scene involving Stan Lee in the library was a nice touch.This Spider-man film completely out-classes the Raimi version and you'd be nuts to think otherwise.

title: Fresh, funny, and thrilled Spiderman!!
text: I was waiting for the movie with quite big expectation, and boy it didn't disappoint me. I enjoyed the movie so much because it looks to me that the maker tried to bring fresh air to Peter Parker character. In the three latest Spiderman movie we can see that the main character is somewhat emo/vulnerable and has been friendzoned for years, but you won't find that in this movie. What I like the most is, beside the funny add-on scenes and fabulous heroine, the fact that this movie showed me more real feeling about being a superhero. Spiderman in this movie didn't just go fly away right away, no, it took time to perfect his move and everything, but that's what interesting. The special effect is very good looking and the fight has actual unexpected major casualties, it makes the movie looks even more real.Indeed, there are some downside like the plot that is a little bit hard to grasp and lack of information (deliberately, it seems) on many important names like Osbourn and Parker's family. However, the fights and the funny scenes could make up for it. You cannot find Spiderman who bring his bag while wearing the costume, actually good looking and charming for the girls, using phones while on action, and still remember to borrow something home in most Spiderman movies.

title: Good Movie
text: It's a very good movie. 3d projection is very much perfect. But it'll be better if story line finished properly. such as we can't see Irfan Khan after hanging from bridge. If you are just looking for blockbusting action and fight scenes from start to finish then no, this movie will probably not deliver for you. However if, as a fan of comic books, you are just as interested in the lives and the motivation of both the heroes and the villains and seeing them have to deal with the same emotional issues that you do, no comic book movie has done it better. Most action scenes were non-thrilling. In a scene where Spiderman rescues a boy from a falling and burning car, he wastes almost 5 minutes trying to convince Jack (the boy) to be brave, climb up and hold his hand. He even gives the boy his mask, but the boy doesn't follow him. So in the end he has to throw his spider-thread to pull Jack up. However, such interesting character development unfortunately does not hold together perfectly with the action. Of course, Spider-Man is foremost a movie that has to entertain; yet the cocky web-slinging CGI hero seems too unlike Garfield's brooding Peter Parker. The quality of the special effects is largely inconsistent, with POV scenes of Spider- Man diving around the city impressing greatly, whilst his actual battles with The Lizard are considerably less ambitious. The weighty retelling of Parker's familiar back-story also means that during the denouement several large plot points, which could have expanded the action, are left undeveloped – and so the ending is a little too simple and unsatisfactory.Webb has successfully addressed the new demand for superhero movies to be deeper and more human; yet he is not a director adept at providing big-budget action to an audience in the same way as Joss Whedon or Christopher Nolan. The Amazing Spider-Man is therefore the sum of two films, a satisfactory coming-of-age movie and a not challenging action film. Unfortunately, Webb is not strong enough to convincingly hold the two together.

title: Best Experience Since Batman Begins For A Movie
text: 7 years ago I was working at a Holiday Inn in TN and a friend of mine came in stating Batman Begins was a must see film. I didn't listen to him for 2 straight weeks but others went to see it at work I finally decided to go see it. I had low expectations and could not take my eyes off the screen! Keep in mind... I don't think Amazing Spider Man is as good than Begins, but it is an excellent movie, and a well written remake. I too had low expectations for this one and was very pleased with the film.I skipped this one in the theaters and rented it on Sunday. This is a feel good movie and well written. In this one, Peter feels like a High Schooler and he and Gwen have a great chemistry on screen. The action is great and I feel anyone that gives this movie a shot will really enjoy it. will not miss Part 2 in the theaters when this one comes out.

title: the amazing spiderman
text: i saw the amazing spiderman a week ago and i must say what an excellent reboot im even going to go as far as saying that this film is way better that the sam rami original it has a great cast great special effect and a great diologe between the characters i am excited to see were this trilogy of new spideman movie go i can not wait for the amazing spiderman 2 coming out may 2 2014 it will be awesome this movie is a great addition to the spiderman world and eny one who is a fan of the spiderman go do your self a favor and go see this movie. now onto the 3d it was awesome as well not the best 3d but still pretty sweet10/10

title: Reboot City!
text: Honestly, I'm one of those guys who hoped like hell for our boy Spidey to join the Marvel Cinematic Universe. I love the idea of the shared universe I think it's genius. That all being said, It's an absolute shame that Garfield was shut down early. He is clearly the better Spider-Man. The chemistry between him and Gwen is real, for obvious reasons. There are some new shot styles in this reboot. The POV shots are incredible. The entire vibe of the movie is much cooler than Tobey Maguire has ever been in his wildest dreams. If only they saved the "Amazing" reboot for the MCU we would all see the most tight butthole movie yet. Emma Stone might be the world's biggest babe. Dennis Leary does a great job with the time he was given, if they let him drop a hard f-bomb that would have shown his true bread & butter.I will absolutely follow up with the sequel, but I can't even wait for him to swing through the MCU.

title: Un Gran Reinicio
text: The Amazing Spider-man es una película grandiosa y entretenida con momentos sorprendentes y divertidos por la partitura musical, las actuaciones (en especial la de Andrew Garfield) , las escenas de acción y ciencia ficción, difícilmente de superar la original del 2002, una de las mejores del 2012 y es recomendada al 87%.

title: Soulless
text: I'm more or less disgusted by the fact that this piece of incoherent plot-hole-riddled and bad acted soulless piece of dumb 3d eye candy for the masses can get a 7.5. The movie has no atmosphere or moods, no character-development, no pay-offs, and some of the most random pacing I've ever seen. It just seems like it's a greedy attempt to keep cashing in on the Spider-Man franchise and nothing more. Even tough the Sam Raimi trilogy had it's flaws, were a bit cheesy and the third movie had a bunch of awkward scenes to say the least, these movies at least had heart, personalty, pacing and steady direction - a comparison with them to this piece of saddening emptiness would feel like the Godfather trilogy compared to Colors. And with a budget with over 225 million dollars the effects where only mediocre - I've seen movies with under half the budget with way more impressive CGI and action sequences.And what was up with the emo/punker/skater spiked-haired and butt-hurt-faced Peter Parker? In the comics he starts out as a quiet nerd and an outsider (which Sam Raimi at least kept faithful to), instead they suddenly change him into this smart-ass teenage hipster rebel with about as much of an interesting personalty as a glass of air. In the original his nerdy and shy nature also made his crush on Mary Jane seem a lot more human and made you care and cheer for him, since she was way more unattainable for him, since she didn't knew about is secrets - in this movie he gets with her before the second act and reveals his secret to her before the third - in the original trilogy this theme kept on going to the end of the second movie.But what bothers me the most is just how stupid it is. Like Spider-Man cap keep on fighting a huge lizard-man with the strength of an elephant, even though he slams him into everything and throws him trough several bookcases and walls (which under normal circumstances would destroy the person before the wall - or at least both), but this hardly makes Spider-Man break sweat or loose stamina, and after-wards he rushes into town and swings acrobatically around and fights cops like he barely got a scratch from his recent encounter with the evil reptile-man, but as soon he is just strafed with a bullet on his leg, he is hardly even able to move, swing or run, like the bullet was made made of Anti-Spider-Man metal, while the sinister crocodile-mans punishment was mere sparring. But of course Spider-Man gets all of his strength and powers back as soon he just sprays his wound with a bit of his old web. And I'm not even going to go into the the little kids dad and his crane-driving buddies and how they managed to coordinate all the constructor-cranes in the town in like 3 minutes to show Spider-Man they loved him. The movie is just full of in-logical and cheesy stuff like this, which just is insulting to anyone who thinks while they're watching a film.To me this movie is as insulting like something like The Phantom Menace or Transformers 3..

title: Best film this year
