Thus, I left the theater asking myself, how long can I keep this up with these re-hashes? How long until interesting ceases to be and becomes just plain insulting?

title: The perfect re-adaptation of the web slinger!
text: First, when I heard of a reboot of the Spiderman franchise,I was scared would it turn out to be disappointing, as I hated the third installment of Sam Raimi trilogy.After getting mixed responses, I was nervous to watch the movie.But after watching, I understood that people are still stuck with the old trilogy and couldn't accept anything new. It was so awesome that I gave a standing ovation to the movie.First of all,talking about Andrew Garfield. This is the version of Spidey that we have seen in the comics,and Garfield had portrayed it with utter brilliance. I mean, he was living, not acting.And the great Lizard, of course. This would be the most wicked portrayal of any Spidey villain in movies after Doc Ock and Electro. I liked the new design. And I forgot to mention,I love the new Spidey outfit!Talking about VFX,I thought that swinging scenes were actually shot,it felt so real that we feel the dynamics of the two characters(Spidey and Lizard),especially the scene where we are introduced to the web slinger, where we feel like we are swinging across the streets of New York along with him.And the story was also great.I liked the action scenes, because they were in appropriate places. Even though the running time is shorter compared to previous installments,I loved it so much. This would be the darkest portrayal of the web slinger ever done in celluloid!

title: Doesn't reach the heights of Spiderman 2, but a great movie nonetheless.
text: Looking back at the previous three Spiderman movies, the 2nd one was the best followed by the 1st, while the 3rd one as we know crashed and burned. This movie -- though it deserves to be looked at by its own -- beats the 3rd one by mile, is somewhat a little better than the first one, but falls way short of the 2nd one (which I consider one of the best superhero movies). This movie goes back the origin of Spiderman and it does well exploring Peter Parker as a character. Unlike Tobey Maguire's Peter Parker, this Peter Parker lacks the charm and sincerity. That being said, Garfield is excellent in portraying the vulnerability and insecurity of Peter Parker, who after all is an adolescent with a big void left in his heart by his parents. This movie drops the innocence and 50's-like atmosphere for a grittier set-in the 21st century feel, in which Peter Parker has a cell phone -- remember Raimi's Parker calling from a payphone?Anyway, the plot line involves the transformation of Dr. Connors into the Lizard, and how Peter Parkerand his parents fit into that. Director Marc Webb has done a great job. More than the action scenes, he has aced in the emotional content of this movie. The scenes between Emma Stone who plays Gwen Stacy and Garfield are brilliant. And what can I say about Emma Stone? She's absolutely a dream.

title: Amazing? Definitely!!
text: so, I saw The Amazing Spider-Man today, needless to say.. I gotta give my review on it.. For starters, I loved it. What we have in this movie is the mix of the 4 core Spider-Man comic titles, which are Peter Parker / Spider-Man, The Amazing Spider-Man, Web of Spider-Man and The Spectacular Spider-Man. For those that are NOT avid Spidey fans, let me explain. Peter Parker / Spider-Man comics was the series that dealt with more of Pete's personal life, The Amazing Spider-Man was were all the characters came together in a big mixing pot, Web of Spider-Man was where all the dark, nitty gritty happened and Spectacular Spider-Man is where all the action on Pete's personal level happened. That being said, ITS ALL in this movie. The movie feels like Web of Spider-Man, has the resolve of Amazing, the action and battle of Spectacular, and the personal story, straight from peter parker / Spider-Man Now, we all know that Spidey's story is and has always been about love for family, friends and the people he cares for.. Its all here in this movie. Andrew does a PHENOMAL job playing Pete and even resembles peter parker from the cover of amazing spider-man vol. 2 #37! Emma Stone as Gwen Stacy is AMAZING. nobody could have done a better job. She was PERFECT in every way, and her chemistry with Andrew is CRAZY! i can definitely see them working on more films together. (and I must admit, I may have dropped a few tears for them ) Rhys Ifans as Curt Conners / The Lizard was excellent as well. I really felt that he did his homework for the part, as he brought the character to life straight from the comics. (and yes, we get to see Lizard with his Labcoat :) ) Aunt May (Sally Field) and Martin Sheen (Uncle Ben) also brought more to their characters as well. (although aunt may's look seemed a little out of touch without her grey hair lol) Captain Stacy (Dennis Leary) has his due too! The entire movie from beginning to end keeps a great steady pace, and does NOT go overboard at the climax of the film but keeps you on the edge of your seat (just like spectacular comics) From the previews you've seen, we get to see Pete's parents, and yes even little petey in a flashback intro to the movie which leads up to a scene where while helping uncle ben in the basement, he comes across an old briefcase that used to belong to his dad...needless to say, he begins to investigate that ends up leading him to Curt Conners in an Oscorp lab. Spider-Man's origin, is untouched pretty much, (still bitten by a spider in a lab) Hilarity ensues upon discovery of his new abilities, and rest assured, the wise-cracking spidey IS in this movie, a lot! unlike the previous 3 spidey films, we get to see a vulnerable spidey, which in the past films he just seemed to "shrug" his hits and bruises off. Although not completely the same, but from this point on you get a feeling of the "Death & Destiny" story from the comics. The special effects are top notch! and I'm sure every pose you have ever seen Spider-Man do, IS IN THIS MOVIE!! From web slinging, to jumping, to diving, to flipping and catapulting! not only that, but when he shoots a web, you can see him push his arm forward as if he was "casting" a fishing line to give his web that extra push. You can see the webbing wobble as its shot, and you can actually FEEL the strength of his webbing just by looking at it. There's SO much more I want to say, but I have to let you all see it with your own eyes. As much as I love the previous trilogy (yes even the 3rd movie, lol) This movie made me realize how too big and bulky, sometimes clumsy feeling Tobey Maguire was as Peter.I still hate the new suit though. hahaI highly recommend this movie to you all, including those that are big fans of Spider-man.I give this movie a solid 4.5 out of 5 stars.In closing, I hope that when and If you do see this film, you will enjoy it as much as I have.

title: Loved Every Minute Of It: Corny, Action-Packed, Even Sappy At Times
text: Amazing indeed. They certainly made the right choice for the role of Peter Parker (Andrew Garfield, an extremely under-appreciated actor) and Summer-Sweetheart Emma Stone as Gwen Stacy. You can't help but love the quirky and awkward chemistry these two have, it gives it that romantic flare that every superhero movie requires for some reason. We start out with a young Peter Parker and his parents who mysteriously vanish for some secretive reason and leave him in the hands of his uncle and aunt. As he grows up, he's the obvious, B-Grade awkward teenager who enjoys riding a skateboard and taking pictures with his old, vintage camera. He's got an an obvious crush on one Gwen Stacy, who's different from Mary Jane in ways that make you root for these two more as a power- couple. She's blonde so you know she's hot, but she wears her it in a ponytail and with straight-across bangs so you know she's a classy, hands-off kind of girl. Peter Parker is less of an outsider in this one and more of a loner. He'a smart and sassy enough to have friends, he just chooses not to. In this reboot, Peter Parker is an effortless genius, chatting it up with soon-to-be-villain as he tries to learn more about his father by talking to this scientist who used to be his father's colleague. Curt Conners is his name, and he's bent on regenerating his arm using lizard DNA. Then they totally lose you and go all scientific, spouting nonsense about algorithms and such until they come up with a formula to regenerate limbs. The formula though has an adverse side-affect that turns you into a monstrous dinosaur-like creature. Soon Connors becomes addicted to the power and tries to destroy the city, blah blah blah, romance brewing, blah blah blah. It's classic superhero flick. So why do I love it so much? I didn't much care for "The Avengers", only so many one-liners can be packed into a non- comedy, and on top of that have an over-enthusiastic battle scene, but this movie did a great job choosing Emma Stone for her role. We know Emma from "Easy A" where she proves she's got the chops for comedy, she's able to a character in this movie without having to have a shtick. Her plucky personality and sun-kissed hair is side-kick gold, and she manages to help out a lot in the end, but it's not so distracting where she's the damsel in distress, unlike Mary Jane who's best assets were complaining and her torso during the kissing-in-the-rain scene. Gwen Stacy likes Peter for Peter, while Mary Jane likes Peter for Spider Man "and I guess Peter too". Andrew Garfield is a great choice for Spider Man. His personality is less over bearing, and his natural flow for things brings more likability than Tobey Maguire ever did. Garfield can joke, while also being serious enough to not ugly-cry so bad it becomes an Internet meme sensation (Tobey Maguire's ugly-cry, Google it). The two stars together are so cute and quirky, it's less forced upon because it's not like the nerd has to beat anyone up or anything like that to get the girl, it happens cuz it happens. The movie of course has that typical Marvel superhero way of making a movie. They care more about audience appeal than they do critic appeal. This movie, however, manages to do both for me. I see it as an enjoyable film, the quirky jokes and one-liners don't bother me because it's less over-bearing. I remember good things rather than being reminded of them. Sure, sometimes the jokes are cheesy, but this movie isn't meant to be taken so seriously. I sometimes detest those Marvel superhero movies for that, but this was a really good crowd-pleaser. The drama in the movie is also not so overbearing so that you forget this is supposed to be an enjoyable movie, but it's good enough so you know this movie's not a total joke. The actors can be serious when they want to, and deliver a better-than-expected performance. And I did enjoy it, the action scenes were riveting, but of course there's that cliché villain who starts out normal, but goes mad because he can't get enough power. It all comes together nicely, and by far surpasses the originals. I can't wait to see Andrew Garfield in the sequels, which you can count on being. Andrew Garfield is the real summer star, much better than butterface Channing Tatum being the constant center of attention, Garfield really deserves it. The only reason it's only a 9 and not a 10 is because of the lack of value it's needs to be an incredible film. It doesn't want to be taken too seriously, like any Nolan DC superhero movie, it wants to be a fan-favorite, and it achieves that on pure likability. It may not be incredible, but it sure is amazing.

title: The Amazing Spider-Man is better than the original
text: The Amazing Spider-Man is better than the original.The film is a re-boot of a franchise that is exactly a decade old, but offers a new and fresh look at the part man, part arachnid that is Peter Parker. The film greatly benefits from its stellar cast led by Andrew Garfield (Social Network) as Peter Parker and Emma Stone (The Help) as Gwen Stacy, who shine in their roles as teenage love interests.Andrew Garfield brings a completely different feel to Peter Parker as an awkward but caring teen who wants to help others, but is also trying to figure out what he really wants. Questions continue to swirl around his parents' mysterious disappearance and Parker wrestles with his feeling of abandonment.Check out my full review here: http://reelstorymovies.blogspot.com/2012/07/amazing-spider-man.html

title: Terrible.
text: I don't even know why I watched this. I was bored. I knew it was gonna be the same old Spider-Man story, AGAIN.Though I didn't expect it to be this bad. This movie is cliché, cheesy, and really really stupid. I really have tried to sit back and accept that maybe this movie isn't supposed to be serious.. its trying to have that comic feel. But no, acting is terrible and jokes are cheap, and it just constantly feels like the creators are looking down at our intelligence. (So many face palm invoking moments..it's just not funny)The first movie franchise started very well compared to this, it had a much better cast and depth (as if this one has any) and- as far as I'm concerned this is an unnecessary, stupefied recycle attempt. If I had not known better I might have thought this is a bad parody. (Something like "Superhero Movie" but that was actually pretty good)It's just sad movies like this are doing well. (But people are gonna keep watching it just because its Spider-Man)

title: Brilliant reboot.
text: Just because its a reboot to a trilogy that just came 10 years ago doesn't mean its going to suck horribly. As a matter of fact, this film was better than the original. Unlike the original, many things in this film are true to the comics, such as Gwen Stacy being Spiderman's first girlfriend, Spiderman having webshooters to shoot web off his wrist, and taking throughout the high school setting. If you're new to this and know about Raimi's Spiderman trilogy, you will find huge differences that were made to be closer to the comics. You won't have Mary Jane as the first girlfriend or Spiderman shooting web organically. Now, onto the film, this film has perhaps some of the best performances in comic book movies. Andrew Garfield ate as both Peter Parker and Spiderman, and I thought he was better than Tobey Maguire. Emma Stone, Rhys Ifans and Denis Leary's acting were fantastic and brilliant. The chemistry between Gwen and Peter is so natural and cute, more than the chemistry between Peter and Mary Jane in the original Spiderman. As for the plot, its a better origin story. Although the villain was a bit weak, I felt the Lizard is more interesting than Raimi's Green Goblin. That's all I've got to say, I would recommend this film to you. I gave it 10 stars out of 10.

title: Great set-up for SpiderMan
text: Spider-Man is funny again! And he's just a kid from New York. And he made his web-slingers. Its a good story. Its fun. As a comic book reader, I'm used to characters getting updated. I mean, if you want the original Hulk he'd be gray with bowl cut. This is a movie that captures the spirit of the character for a modern audience. Could there be more Green Goblin, HobGoblin, Hobgoblin 2, Vermin, Kraven, and eventually an opening for the return of Mary Jane? Some great stories are waiting. Will SpiderMan get to meet Dr. Strange? I hope so!This movie has a Spider-Man that could get in a fight with DareDevil, poke fun at Iron Man, and save the Multi-verse with Dr. Strange. Unfortunately, thanks to multiple studios owning the rights and being unlikely to negotiate, they will never benefit from the "soap opera" cross over that makes comic books so good at selling more comic books.

title: the amazing spider-man!:)
text: After watching all the previous Spider-Man movies, I had doubts with regards to this movie but it was worth the watch. It shines on its own and it is a nice start if they want to continue making sequels. Nice CG, Nice acting and nice story. The fight scenes are uniquely done. Andrew Garfield is also a very good pick for Peter Parker. Kudos also to Emma Stone. Spider-Man 1 and 2 were very great. Especially because it seems lively and it tackles the day to day problem of Peter Parker. This movie is not lively though. It is dark. The Spider-Man here fights smartly and uses his environment more. Although I liked the old costume more and that the Peter Parker here seemed like a troubled teen.. this really was a nice watch.:)

title: Dull, poorly structured and stupid
text: OK, so after the 3rd Spiderman movie they felt they needed to start again. Only problem was we already had an established character, so why bother telling this again？Well obviously they wanted to cash in on the whole serious Batman trilogy. Only problem is all you end is the same story we have seen before with a character playing Peter Parker who looks like it was scripted by someone whose idea of cool is based on Bart Simpson.The result is dull and uninteresting. The previous Spiderman was the perfect comic book movie and now we have this rubbish that takes itself way too seriously.

title: Great Acting/Directing/Composer/Score/Soundtrack/Drama
text: I was extremely pleased with this adaptation of Spiderman. First off, and not necessarily foremost, Andrew Garfield is a much more dramatic actor then Toby Maguire. Of course all the credit cant belong to Garfeild, but also the director and composer, and in Maguires defense he can really only work with what the director gives him to work with, however I still hold Garfield superior as an actor. The building blocks were laid from the get go in order to build an understanding and emotional connection of Peters unresolved conflicts. An emotional connection was established between the viewers and characters resulting in real drama. The comic relief was tasteful, kept to a minimum, and for what i can recall, no cheesiness. The Score and soundtrack I thought was phenomenal. I have read that some think there was not enough action and used that as a bases of their dis-satisfaction. A great movie needs more than non-stop action and special effects. It needs believable characters and emotion. It needs a good story and good acting/directing along with a good score to serve as something of a backbone for the feeling and drama of a movie as well as what the characters are going through. If one puts to much action in a movie, there is less space for more important components that contribute to a great movie. The last Spiderman franchise I think i watched the first one a couple times and the second one once, and was not interested in watching the third so I didn't. I didn't believe the Toby Maguire Spiderman. The new one made a believer out of me. This movie blew me away and met a lot of the criteria that i hold important in a movie. I greatly look forward to the next two installments.

title: Continuing Spider-Man
text: Spectacular! That is one way to describe this film as it not only expresses the action and adventure of a teenage superhero, but also the life of being a teenager. This film captures both those aspects better than the Tobey Maguire Spider-man films. With Tobey, I always felt that the spider-man films had a strong adult present when the super-hero was in fact JUST finishing high school.Every actor in this film was very important to the way the story moved as they would show conflict, bravery, fright, and courage. From the actors to the directors of this film, I thank all of them for creating such an amazing experience, never, to be forgotten.

title: Sorry as excuse of a reboot just to rake in some cash.
text: If you have seen the previous Spider Man then don't waste your time watching this Spider Man. It was very childish not just compared to the Sam Raimi Spider Man but just on its own to. The Spider Man is basically the same story as the previous first Spider Man with minimal changes. From my understanding Sony was set to produce Spider Man 4 with the old cast and crew returning. Sam Raimi wanted an extended release date for the film so he could get it right but Sony was set against it. Sony wanted the cash cow franchise to rake in cash early. Sam Raimi felt he would not finish in time so Sony and the director parted ways. Sony released The Amazing Spider Man on the sole intent of making money. The fans interests were last priority to them. No franchise should be rebooted that fast. When comparing the Marc Webb Spider Man and the Sami Raimi Spidr Man the Sam Raimi take was much more mature. Remember...both Spider Man takes are both modern day takes and had big budgets and access to great special effects. Thus it comes down to who could direct the better movie. Sam Raimi wins by a long shot. Tobey Maguire portrayed a much more realistic nerd than Andrew Garfield. The Sam Raimi Spider Man had bigger and more entertaining set pieces. Last is the special effects and cgi. Marc Webb's movie looked way to fake. You could tell the burning cars were fake and the Lizard character looked to cartoonish. The smoke bombs the Lizard released looked like some out of a video game.

title: Amazing Isn't Good Enough To Describe This Movie/ Incredible!
text: I went to see this movie at the midnight showing, and yes I am a HUGE Spider-man fan so I may be a little biased but i went to see it multiple times and did see a few mistakes so this review will be reliable! The Amazing Spiderman is the reboot of Sony's acclaimed spiderman movies, and in my opinion, they created a new peak for the movies. Sam Raimi's spiderman flicks were good at points but going back to see them, they are now just very silly and stupid. The Amazing Spiderman is a very spectacular interpretation of the comics. Even though the producers took from a few other comic series, this spiderman flick did stay true to the comics and left me crying of happiness in the end. The story of how Peter Parker is yes, retold but in the true way. Where he makes the web-shooters! (Not where he can freaking shoot unrealistic webs out of his wrists! Like What the heck!) Which is kind of rushed in ways, but I think is necessary because of the "oh I get it" factors that come from the quick shots. Other than that the movie is very well timed and edited. The cast is AMAZING!! Andrew Garfield plays a great Spiderman. All of the twitches and random, qwerky, little things that he does just add to making him a great Peter Parker. Peter Parker is a geek, an outcast, a nerd! I expect the actors to portray that well and thats exactly what Andrew did. Also as Spiderman he makes great smart-a remarks and shows off the strength and sheer skill of Spiderman perfectly. Emma Stone plays a wonderful Gwen Satcy and actually has brains as a character unlike the Sam Raimi movies. All aroudn this movie is great! I'd give it six gazillion thumbs up if I had that many thumbs, hope this review helps and I hope all of you readers make the right decision in choosing to see this movie!!

title: This is only for those who love the ridiculous
text: I must say that the casting took a different role and did not cast according to looks. The child at the beginning of the movie looked more like the woman that Parker is in love with than Parker himself. One must notice that the boy had a round face and very small chin while Peter Parker had a long face and prominent chin. The woman had a round face and not a prominent chin. The special effects look like nothing but cartoons. I give the special effects people a zero on this film. I could hardly watch this film as it has no capacity to even keep one involved. The fact that there is a sequel amazes me. poorly written,very poor acting and the lack of story only shows that comic book people will love anything. This so called movie would be great if a 13 year old child had written the script. The acting is sometimes good and sometimes very bad. The man who plays the father of Spider-mans love is a very bad actor or he has been given a very bad script. If I was 5 years old. I would love this movie.

title: 'The Amazing Spider-Man' (My Mini Review)
text: I just finished watching, 'The Amazing Spider-Man'. I was going to write a long review, but I changed my mind. I'll just say I watched it on IMAX & 3D and it was an enjoyable experience. Watching Spider-Man swing around and climb walls was bad ass. The problem I have with 3D glasses though, is I've always felt it looks a bit to dark for my taste. That said, if you are a fan of 3D movies I highly recommend watching it this way. As far as the film itself, it was a great reboot. I won't sit here and tell you that it was better then Tobey Maguire's version because the original was magical. I mean, who could forget Chad Krueger's "Hero" music video and everything else that came from that movie? "With great power comes great responsibility". Come on! It doesn't get any better then that. I could watch that movie 100 times and still love it. However, I have to give credit to some improvements that the reboot did. I like Emma Stone as Gwen Stacy. Emma doesn't annoy me like Kristen Dunst. She has chemistry with Andrew Garfield who plays the new Spider-Man. When she smiles, she makes me smile and I like that. In fact I'm at the movies thinking, "I want her as my girlfriend". I also think that Peter Parker wasn't as nerdy this time around, so he was more believable. Again, I'm not going to write a 20 page review. I will just say that I enjoyed it. If the original was a 10 then this would be like a 9 and that's not taking anything away from it because I DID love it and I'll see it again. I think this version has a bit more back story, but not to much. The debate of which Spider-Man is better will be talked about, but in the end it all comes down to the creators. Both Spidey's were portrayed different and each actor did great in his role. It's like people that continue to debate which is the better Joker. Jack Nicholson or Heath Ledger. BOTH were awesome! It just comes down to how you like your character to be portrayed. One is more light-hearted and one is all dark and serious. The Lizard was a cool villain. The action scenes kicked ass. Its f*cking Spider-Man. How can it not be cool? I love Spider-Man. I grew up watching all the cartoons and even the 70's TV show that had cool pimp music as the opening theme song. Again, I could say so much more, just go watch it and enjoy it and stay for one extra scene during the credits. That is all.

title: Stop now
text: Stop making Spiderman movies. I never understood why this new movie needed to be made, so shortly after the last three with Tobey Maguire. I mean, the concept has been milked to the max, nothing could be added and indeed, this movie doesn't add anything. The story is pretty lame, the characters aren't surprising, different, or in any other way interesting and the new bad guy is just plain boring, if not at least completely superficial. Lizardman misses his arm, co th entire city needs to be transformed into lizards??? Please, that's just dumb...Sure, the special effects are nice and advanced, but that is absolutely not enough to carry this movie to any noticeable heights.I would not give this sad attempt more than a three and why the F.. it gets a sequel? I dunno...

title: Not bad for a guy in a skintight red and blue suit
text: I watched this tonight and I was one of those who was not skeptical of a spiderman reboot. Being a huge fan of spiderman, i was eager to see what Webb had to offer and he delivers a spiderman which has so much more substance than Raimis version.One of the best things about this film is the fact that the spiderman stunts were done with wires and as little cg as possible and it has paid off because it looks authentic and believable! The fight scenes are very good and really shows how agile spiderman is. In Raimi's spiderman, i think it lacks this quality. Also Webb made sure that this incarnation of spiderman cracks a few jokes just like its comic counterpart. Webb also does a great job with the character development. The chemistry between Parker and Stacy is great and the acting from Andrew Garfield and Emma Stone is brilliant. I really enjoyed Garfield as Parker/spiderman. Some issues i did have with the movie is that it has that "mysterious" plot line running through the film with peters parents which may just be something for future films but does niggle at you throughout the film and also some of the highschool scenes, although they were fun felt abit strange in the film as Webb does set a dark tone in the film which again distinguishes it from Raimi's version. Positives: Great action scenes, great acting and characters Negatives: "cryptic" plot line in some places, pacing is good but some places are abit quick Overall: Definite must see, great movie and i think it is superior to Raimi's version.

title: Best Spider-Man Origin Yet
text: Note: For you to really enjoy this movie, you have to think that the Sam Raimi versions never existed and if you can't do that, just don't compare it to Spider-man 1-2-3. It's great that I was never a fan of the Raimi versions.On to the review.The Amazing Spider-man is simply amazing as the title puts it. It's a much more realistic approach for Peter Parker's Origin. The chemistry between Peter Parker and Gwen Stacy is seen and felt in each of the scenes they were in. Martin Sheen's Uncle Ben is very charismatic. He may never have a great quote for Peter but what he gave was more than words as you really feel what he says. Sally Field's Aunt May isn't utilized more in the movie and in some reviews that I've read prior to watching the movie says she was one of the weakest link of the film but for me, she was not. Curt Connors/The Lizard is quite OK as the main villain. CGI looks great. How Spider-man moves and poses are brought to life well. Awesome fight scenes. Jokes are funny and not forced funny.Though the movie is awesome, it is not perfect. The 2 hour long running time of the film seems a bit short and it shows. Some scenes are not as well established as they were supposed to be so I'd assume they were cut for shorter running time. I wouldn't have mind if the movie was 3 hours long since the movie is far from boring.Awesome movie and definitely worth the admission ticket.

title: Smart is the new sexy!
text: Ten years later,Peter Parker has evolved.He is smart,he is sexy,and he's not an orphan.(he is just abandoned)and he can do way more cool stuff than stopping trains.I got to see this movie in India where it released on June 29th. The movie begins with the same old storyline.Peter Parker is a nerd,abandoned by this parents and there's this girl he really likes(Emma). In these times of hair dying and cosmetics surgery,even parker's uncle and aunt couldn't let their temptations run away....now they are like really cool hippies or something,but they still care if there peter gets beaten up by bad guys or forget to buy the eggs.Throughout the first part of the film you get the "Seen it already,Know it already" feeling and all your predictions come true...the uncle dies(God knows how much I wanted that guy to die....he was just harsh on the ears),Our new amazing spider gets to kick some bully ass....and it goes like this for pretty much time.Just before the interval,you realize that well...you have adapted to the new guy...now He isn't a dork,all his stupid dialogs make sense......Mark WEBB's WEBB has finally caught you. The movie seems interesting,The 3D is amazing(3ality technology used),It isn't the one which you'll not able to feel or feel too much.Just Perfect. The background score is Terrible,It just fails to give you that EPIC war feeling....it just lays flat every time.Andrew and Emma share a great chemistry.(NOTICE THE WAY HE ADMITS HIS LOVE WHEN YOU WATCH THE FILM). The CGI looks awesome.......(not a bit blurry ,even in 3d).Well, some will not be able to cope up with this new Mr.Speak-too-much spider-man ......but Mark will surely make you fall in this long lasting WEBB,if not now then surely later. Make sur you witness the beginning of new era.

title: great new origin story with good casting, especially Andrew Garfield, some fun action and palpable drama
text: I won't go into comparing this iteration with others within the Spider-Man movies, except to say that Andrew Garfield is easily my second favorite Peter Parker if not tied for first. I just think he's an excellent actor and anyone who disagrees should dive into Silence (2016) and Hacksaw Ridge (2016). Anyway, he's splendid in this, exuding both humor and drama seamlessly. Rhys Ifans as Curt Connors is also great, especially as his character metastisizes. The CGI for the Lizard is done very well and I just loved his/its scenes. They add a very animalistic, borderline horror element that most superhero villains don't have. And while the movie takes a little over an hour to really showcase Parker as Spider-Man, it never feels like it drags or bores.

title: Pretty pointless reboot.
text: Why was this made? I ask you, why? We know the story and there is nothing wrong with how it was told in the Sam Raimi versions, so why? to be darker and please the comic fans, or to make more money. Hmm...how bout both. Seriously, this does nothing more than change the cast around and tell the story quicker, nothing more.Andrew Garfield plays an okay Spider-Man with the wise cracking and confidence etc, but his Peter Parker does not hold a candle to Tobey Maguire. He plays it more normal and straightforward, rather than nerdy, which is what Peter Parker is. Gwen Stacey is a huge improvement over Mary Jane which I liked, but their chemistry starting out is awkward and stupid. The villain is a friend of Peter's dad, Curt Connors, who develops a serum that could grow back his arm, but instead turns him into a horrible looking CGI lizard. Although the fights with the lizard are unique and he isn't the worst Spider-man villain we've seen, he's still ugly as sh*t and dies pretty simply. The film is style over substance, and the style is not that interesting. It's dull and it's trying too hard to change the way it tells the story. Nothing stood out that I haven't all ready seen. The death of Uncle Ben is not only brushed aside like nothing, but he's not even what motivates Peter to become Spider- Man. No, it's Denis Leary playing the police chief, and Gwen's father.When something stylized in the film works, it works well enough to get by, but definitely not enough to really enjoy. Would not recommend unless you're a big fan of the comics.

title: Finesse
text: Alright so The Amazing Spider-man... definitely redeemed the past spidey films but it's ever so slightly and mildly disappointing I can't quite put my finger on it; other than maybe i was just tooo excited going into the film. But overall its an actual movie to watch. Nearly standalone, which is to say there's more movie to watch than there is actual Spidey action! which is great. overall though its the best spiderman yet! not cheesy like tobey maguire...its up to par with the, relatively new, superhero genre. It was a bit more charming as far as not emphasizing his new powers as this big huge deal. it was just a high school kid who had some physical changes happen. It was more graceful and more tasteful. You see him grow into Spider-man in this film but not as a superhero. He grows into a man with purpose who just so happens to be a 'spider-dude' Whereas the past films were heavily focused on him being a superhero and the duality of his life that it becomes too distant to relate too....This movie also doesn't have a hard hitting ONE thing that needs to be accomplished, You see he has himself to figure out, uncle ben, aunt may, Dr. Connors to deal with, Gwen Staci and her father, and Parker's parents' story. I'm assuming a lot of people won't like it simply because they need to be spoon-fed their movies. The Amazing Spider-man doesn't have a million explosions and guns blazing! He doesn't develop powers and then change his entire outlook on the universe and view himself as this ultra-important god-like being that needs to save the world. He more or less uses his abilities, sometimes!, as would most of us in his position. We wouldn't just morph into this absurdly next-level being, which he is, it's just not the focus of the film and it's not even Parker's focus in the film. much more real, easy to relate to. i think the key word for this film is: finesseMust See! and must remove Sam Raimi's films from memory. This is the only Spider-Man.

title: Would love for it to have been longer
text: I know im almost a decade too late but i still want to give my input.I know the movie isn't the best but it gives a refreshing take on the spiderman movies it may be needed but its one on the best movies in my heart but maybe i'm biased i am a very bog fan on Garfield and Stone, i would watch this movie in repeat when it first came out I may have only been 20 but i new that this was a movie of agees the chinamaphogrphy is a 10/10 its own. And i like how they used a different love interest of peter parker im no film bro but i will talk about this movie for hours it may just be me talking about how Garfild looked 'edible' and now to the actual review.The acting may have not been 12 oscars and 30 emmys deserving but it was still good a true reflection of the 2010 and was kinda realistic about american high school things that Miguers lacked some areas and the soundtrack hold a special place in my heart. The CGI was good considering it was 2012 personally i loved the swinging scenes are my favorite at times they cab be very up close and personal still they are good. Now onto the plot it could be better but it could be worse the acting made it better then it should be some lines that would have been a cringe fest if a lesser actor delivered them thankfully they are good actors. In conclusion The amazing spider-,man is one of the best movies of the 2010s.

title: He is new and modern.
text: The Amazing Spider-Man. He is new and modern. Andrew Garfield coped with the role of a spider. It does not look like a Tobey Maguire spider, and that's good. A more dynamic and more teenage film gave a great start for the new Spider-Man series.

title: Lame Reboot
text: When you reboot a franchise, the goal is to give the story a shot of stimulants to get it going again. Just like the recent Star Trek reboots, the Amazing Spider-Man does give the franchise a little boost, especially after the flawed and unfocused Spider-Man 3. However, it isn't the most groundbreaking, either. We have to get the origin story going again - although this time we get a little more into Peter Parker's absent parents. Once the story gets going, we are introduced to Dr. Curt Connors - AKA the Lizard. In all honesty, this was a great villain - probably the best one Spidey faced in the comics of yore. This was a flawed person that Spider-Man/Parker was always trying to help and redeem. We also have two vintage comic characters, Gwen Stacey and Captain Ned Stacey. Yes, they were introduced in Raimi's campy Spider-Man 3, but they were out of sync with the canonical story. This fresh take, does keep with the older comic stories and characters - and with Parker developing the web on his own. There was also a good casting call of making Martin Sheen who made a great Ben Parker. Sally Field, though, as Aunt May seemed a little weak as opposed to Rosemary Harris who gave the character a lot of strength. The one miscast (slightly) was Andrew Garfield as the new Parker/Spider- Man. I'm sorry, but Garfield did not give us the nerdy outcast vibe Maguire gave us. I thought the story moved a little slow. This one is also darker than the previous installments. It does not, however, resort to the camp and silliness of the previous Spidey venture. Overall, though, it was a fun time at the movies. It was not as fun as Raimi's first two ventures, but still enjoyable.

title: Above average remake
text: Much is expected of spider man as to the former image as a comic character and the brilliant work by Toby Maguire in the former series. The movie does well on the effects and technology but does not go well in adding to the depth. Spider-man seems to demolish its earlier image and convert into a wit making lad. Not on expected lines.

title: A really good Spider-Man movie
text: I just got around to this take on Spider-Man. It's pretty obvious they are rebooting this franchise too quickly, and there's only so many versions I can handle. I liked Toby's Spidey, I like Tom's Spidey.Now I like Andrew's Spidey too!I won't try to rank them, I think they all have nailed the part.But I think this might be my favorite Spidey film. This one really balances the drama and wit of Spider-Man. There are extravagant fx, but they service the story and don't feel like they are the centerpiece.This film reminds me of the first Superman movie, 1978, in a very good way. That was the first major film of a superhero where you could actually start to believe it's a real life person in our real world.Denis Leary's Captain Stacy is pitch perfect, and Stacy and Peter's argument about the role of Spidey and the police in enforcing law and justice in the city is an absolute delight.I also like that Spidey's identity isn't held quite so tight. My one complaint here is that one character's demise didn't seem necessary.

title: "The Amazing Spider-Man" is pretty good
text: In honor for the the release of "The Amazing Spider-Man 2," I decided to review this before going to see the sequel. So, with that said, here is my review. Five years after "Spider-Man 3" came out, which it received mixed reaction by critics and fans alike Sam Raimi and the rest of cast of the original three movies decided to leave the franchise, and have Sony reboot it with a new director and a new set of cast. Marc Webb, director of one of my favorite movies of 2009 500 Days of Summer comes in to direct along with Andrew Garfield taking over the role of Spider-Man and his alter ego Peter Parker. I did go see this movie in theaters, and I really like it. However, I don't love it as much as what others say. You want to know why? Well, I wasn't really that much fond of rebooting series and have Sam Raimi along with the original cast leave the franchise, and not do a fourth Spider-Man movie. I understand that "Spider-Man 3" left many comic book fans disappointed, and consider to be the worst of the series. To me, I don't hate "Spider-Man 3" as what they said. I can see what were the problems in that movie, but I still have so fun with it and I do wish if there was a "Spider-Man 4." Raimi did said that he was unhappy with the results, but does not hated it; he also said that he wanted go back to basics like what the original first two movies were. The unmade fourth movie was going to feature the Lizard or Vulture in this movie, and maybe feature Felicia Hardy as the Black Cat; although they were going to make her as the Vulturess instead which it sounds lame, but they can at least rewrite it and make her the Black Cat as the character should be. But nope, the people at Sony decided to reboot the franchise instead of continuing it. So much of the disagreements between Sony and Raimi had. I still would've love see "Spider-Man 4" happening, but nevertheless, I did accepted it as a conclusion for Sam Raimi's trilogy. So that is one of the problems that I had with "The Amazing Spider-Man." Also, I thought James Horner's score along with the Spider Man theme isn't as amazing as Danny Elfman's; its not bad though, but its not one of my favorites. Lastly, we don't need to tell Spider-Man's origin story again. I understand why it needed to be told because we never see Peter Parker's parents in the original movies, and trying to make Uncle Ben's killer right because of what happened in "Spider-Man 3." It is well told, but it still doesn't need to be told again. The movie itself is almost like watching the original first Spider-Man movie all over again, and it makes you wonder what is the point. If they just take out the origin, then maybe the movie would be a little better. So those are my problems with the movie. Despite some of the flaws that I mention, I did thought that Marc Webb had done a terrific job on directing the movie, while Andrew Garfield does a great job to play both Spider-Man and Peter Parker. No need to compare which Spider-Man is better because I enjoy Garfield's and Tobey Maguire's for each of their own take. Emma Stone I will admit is a much better Gwen Stacey than what Bryce Dallas Howard did in "Spider-Man 3." Howard is okay, but I prefer Stone's more. The relationship between Peter and Gwen is quite good, but I rather much prefer Peter and Mary Jane because that is how I remember as a kid growing up when there was the 1994 animated series. Martin Sheen and Sally Field were great as Peter's uncle and aunt, while Rhys Ifans does a fine job as the Lizard. The special effects are pretty darn good. The suit that Spider-Man wore is not bad, but I prefer the old suit in the original movies more. The action scenes were fine, but there is nothing spectacular about it. So that is all I got to say about whats good and bad about it. "The Amazing Spider-Man" is pretty good, and I give it an 8 out of 10. Seriously, I still wish if there was a "Spider-Man 4."

title: I'm biased, but this movie is awesome.
text: I love this movie. But I'm biased. I love Andrew Garfield as Spider-Man. Hell, he's my favorite Spider-Man. While I'm biased, I'm not gonna shove this movie in your face and say, "Oh, tHiS MoViE iS ThE BeSt sPiDeR-mAn MoViE oF aLL TiMe!!!!1!1!1" No, I'm not gonna say that. I understand why people don't like this movie. I will admit, they made some stupid mistakes, but in my opinion, they're not as big as the good parts. The story is simple, (and has problems) but effective. The acting is incredible, Andrew Garfield and Emma Stone have great chemistry, and it's visible to stay. Visuals are good, not mind blowing, but good. So yeah, you should check it out.

title: The law of creativity trumps the law of gravity
text: As a child growing up in the 80s, I was fortunate that my imagination was not burdened by as many technological trappings that plague kids today. Sure, I had my Atari and Nintendo, but beyond that I had a group of creative friends and a few backyards that became various universes. And while I was blessed to have many real heroes in my life, I still had a fascination for a few superheroes that weren't limited by the laws of gravity and physics. Batman and Spider-Man were always my favorites, and I may or may not have had the footie pajamas to prove it.That sense of wonder didn't end as a child. The magic of the movies can still create a bond with those memories of old when it's done right. On one hand, Christopher Nolan has found a way to expertly filter the Batman universe through the perspective of my adult mind. On the other hand, my inner child still relates to a character like Spider-Man. Not only did I love the fact that he was just a geeky kid who stood up to bullies, but let's be honest – his mask is awesome.But, like many, I was skeptical about a new franchise so soon after the Sam Raimi and Tobey Maguire incarnation. Those films had their flaws (particularly Kirsten Dunst and the lack of any semblance of chemistry between her and Maguire), but the first two were highly enjoyable. Was a reboot necessary? Was it needed this soon? Then I thought about Maguire's stupid disco dancing in Spider-Man 3 and I began to think, "You know what, why not? Let's give somebody else a shot at this." That thought and a couple of promising trailers later, and I was a little more on board. Now I had to be sold.Consider the sell complete.Sure, this is familiar territory. So what? Director Marc Webb has found a way to take a story most of us already know and put a fresh spin on it. I have many friends who will probably call me a traitor for this, but I loved Andrew Garfield as Peter Parker/Spider-Man. In fact, I think he's even more believable than the aforementioned Maguire. He creates a likable, relatable character who is as awkward with the ladies as most of us guys were in high school, and he gives Spider-Man just enough sense of humor without stepping over the line into cheesiness. The scene where he "cowers" at a small knife demonstrates what I mean.We also get a better glimpse at just how intelligent he is. For example, we see that Peter's web-shooting ability is his own creation, as it was originally presented in the comics.Garfield's chemistry with Emma Stone's Gwen Stacy is handled with both believability and subtlety. I couldn't care less about the absence of Mary Jane. In the comics, Gwen was Spidey's first love, and Ms. Stone portrays her with just the right combination of intelligence and sass.Rhys Ifans is also a stand-out as Dr. Curt Connors/The Lizard. He takes a character that isn't as widely beloved as others in the Spider-Man universe, and he creates a villain that is downright menacing at times and sympathetic at others. We get more than just a one-note bad guy with little more than world domination as his goal. Ifans delivers a character struggling with severe inner conflict who has both evil and redemption at his fingertips.With a budget estimated at more than $200 million, the cinematography and action sequences are as beautiful as you would expect, providing the excitement and wonder that kids and adults alike desire when sitting down to be taken into a different world. And while the film hits all the right adventurous notes; it's the relationships and the actors who develop them that give the film its heart.Call me sappy, but I couldn't help but feel the film's climax is as heroic as it is thrilling. Not only was I immersed in what was happening on screen, but I was briefly transported to my backyard when burdens were light, stress was low, and imagination was high.Complain about reboots if you want. Whine about inconsistencies with the original comic if it makes you feel better. As for me, that stuff never bothered me as a child, and it's not something that bothers me now. All I ask for with a movie like this is to be taken to a different world where the laws of gravity and physics matter less than the law of creativity, and The Amazing Spider-Man does just that.Batman is still my all-time favorite superhero, but Spider-Man is close behind. Even if I don't still have the footie pajamas to prove it.Honestly, I don't! But I will take the mask...

title: A Bold New Direction
text: I personally enjoyed this film when it first came out back in 2012 and didnt have any issues with it. Fast forward to 2023 and I still enjoyed The Amazing Spider-Man it's not perfect or a masterpiece like Sam Raimi's first Spider-Man movie, Amazing Spider-Man is still great in of it's selfIt's definitely a lot darker filled with mystery and intrigue . I like the fact this was the only Spider-Man movie to bring in Peter's biological parents and have them die in a plane crash and have this whole big mystery as to why they died in the first place. What were they investigating? Who was after them? It was a good choice I felt and in some ways this movie is sort of similar to Batman Begins. Peter and Bruce were both vengeful looking to punish those that killed their parents or in Pete's case his uncle. They both eventually overcome their vengeful pride to become better people and use their skills for the benefit of mankindDr Connors/ The Lizard in this movie was fairly decent not as memorable as Willem Dafoe's Green Goblin, Alfred Molina's Doc Ock or Jamie Fox's Electro but he was still good. Could have been developed a little more but it's fineLoved the fact they used Gwen Stacy instead of doing what the Raimi films did and automatically go for MJ. I have nothing against MJ, she's good but Gwen was Peter's first true love before MJ in the comics so it made sense to bring her into this universe of Spider-Man first. Didnt really care for Gwen's fatherOverall this movie was great it was setting the foundations for a cinematic universe that sadly never took off after the reviews of Amazing Spider-Man 2, the mystery and overarching story of what happened to Peter's parents, finding Uncle Ben's killer that never really got solved and the first to try and set up a future Sinister Six movie that also never happened.

title: Not that amazing!
text: Now this isn't a bad movie it's actually enjoyable to watch. The visuals are good, it has good shots, and the action scenes are on spot! I also liked how they made Peters parents somewhat connected to Peter getting his powers.What I didn't like about it was it's special effects and CGI it was so bad to look at. And I don't know about other people but I am getting tired of rebooting franchises.I also don't like that they didn't get Uncle Ben to give his most iconic line "with great power comes great responsibility". How come we didn't get that!When it came to the cast I thought they weren't bad. Andrew Garfield wasn't bad as Spider-Man and he was perfect for Peter Parker especially! Emma Stone plays the love interest as Gwen Stacy and she doesn't do a bad job at it. Rhys Ifans plays the Lizard and the problem I have with that was he was mostly CGI the most of the time and we maybe saw him in physical form for like 20 minutes and the Lizard wasn't as terrifying as the green goblin for as tragic as Dr. Octopus.Overall it's a good movie but could have been way better.

title: "Amazing Spider-Man" weaves a strong though familiar web
text: Back in 2002, Sony Pictures and filmmaker Sam Raimi brought one of Marvel Comics' most popular superheroes, Spider-Man, to big screen for the first time. Peter Parker's story captivated audiences and set the record for the most money made on an opening weekend.Now, let's imagine none of that ever happened. Let's pretend director Marc Webb and Sony brought movie-goers "The Amazing Spider-Man" for the first time ever in 2012. What's the result? A box-office record would be doubtful given the era we live in, but a powerful story that captivates audiences — absolutely. It would've been hailed as just as if not more of an incredible film in 2002.Well, it's not 2002, and we can't pretend forever. As such, the one major thing that will draw ire toward "The Amazing Spider-Man" is that it tells a story that came to the big screen 10 short years ago. It's not a conversation that would even happen if this were 2032, but this context is a reality.For a child who is now a teenager, this could turn out to be a defining film with two stars of a younger generation in Andrew Garfield and Emma Stone, but a good chunk of audience members will wait and wait for the film to deliver some revelatory change to the story they already know that never comes.It's always important to be aware of your own expectations, but if you want to be able to appreciate the multiple strengths of "The Amazing Spider-Man," it's a recommendation that can't be taken lightly. So here it goes: this is Spider-Man's origin story. There are new actors, and some new characters that make it look different, but it's Spider-Man's origin story.To come clean on biases, I love Spider-Man's origin story. There's nothing more powerful in the comic universe than the way Peter Parker comes of age and into his role as a hero in a traumatic flash, losing someone he loves when he chooses to act thoughtlessly and selfishly. So on one hand, you could say I have a predilection toward this movie because it tells that story; on the other hand, I'm very particular about it. I need to feel it or I'll be disappointed. In this "Spider-Man," you definitely still feel it.The presentation of the movie is different than the 2002 film, but its core and messages are the same. Uncle Ben doesn't say "with great power comes great responsibility," but he basically paraphrases it. Call that repetitive if you will, but it's absolutely crucial to Spider-Man. It would be dishonorable toward the comics to handle it any other way, not to mention give little reason for you to care about Garfield's version of Peter Parker.Different from the original film, Peter is severely affected by a complete lack of resolution regarding his parents. He loves his Uncle Ben (Martin Sheen, who is superb) and Aunt May (Sally Field), but his parents' disappearance haunts him, so the discovery of an Oscorp file belonging to his father and a lead in the form of man who was his father's old research partner, Dr. Curt Connors (Rhys Ifans), sends Peter's curiosity into overdrive. Doing so lands him on the path to getting bit by the radioactive spider and becoming Spider-Man.Peter goes from extraordinary teen to masked crime-fighter for selfish reasons after the death of Uncle Ben. Whereas Peter believes he gets his revenge in the 2002 film (we learn he didn't in "Spider-Man 3″), failing to find his uncle's killer adds more painful irresolution to his life. It's a void he eventually realizes he can fill with heroism, and considering he gives Dr. Connors the formula that will later turn him into the The Lizard, stopping him is a chance to finally correct one of his mistakes.Peter also finds a confidant in Gwen Stacy (Stone), daughter of the police chief (Denis Leary) and the man who wants Spider-Man to answer to the law. Gwen actually learns of his identity, and the two even work together to stop Connors, another refreshing change from the damsel in distress motif that permeated all of Raimi's films. Yet Peter and Gwen's relationship still has that tragic quality true to the comics.From the romance to the science to the action, "The Amazing Spider-Man" has a decidedly more realistic feel than the Raimi films (and little of their campy humor), a fact likely to go under-appreciated given that we live in a post-The Dark Knight world. To be fair to that first trilogy, however, it did ground itself in real themes and emotions, but so does this movie. The second and third Spider-Man movies share a screenwriter with this reboot in Alvin Sargent, and the way the story is constructed feels extremely similar to those previous adventures.Even with all the quality writing full of strong themes and proper character motivation, "The Amazing Spider-Man" gets long in the tooth, especially as you wait for the origins to be fully rehashed with Peter getting his powers, playing around with his powers, etc. The third act, however, turns out to be an exhilarating finish and then some. The action (both in choreography and CGI in all acts of the movie) knocks the original trilogy off a skyscraper. And when it seems like the emotional flourish won't come, the script finds some fitting and effective moments of catharsis for all the characters.Yes, it's frustrating seeing something similar unfold that's fresh in our minds, but for a new Spider-Man franchise to emerge in the dust of the old one, these origin essentials needed to be covered, and they're covered exceptionally well. We have a whole new cast of lovable characters now, and Sony and Webb have earned their license (and our trust) to take the trilogy where they want it to go, which looks to be deeper into the mystery of the Richard and Mary Parker.
