title: The Best Spider-Man Movie Ever
text: Watched The Amazing Spider-Man with Andrew Garfield(The Social Network) as Peter Parker/Spider-man, The Lovely Emma Stone(Easy A) as Gwen Stacy ,Martin Sheen(The Departed) as Ben Parker,Sally Field (Homeword Bound:The Incredible Journey) as Aunt May ,Chris Zylka(Shark Night 3D) as Flash Thompson, Denis Leary(Ice Age) as George Stacy ,Irrfan Khan (Slumdog Millionaire) as Doctor Ratha, and Rhys Ifans(Harry Potter And The Deathly Hollows) as Doctor Curt Connors/The Lizard. I Really Enjoyed The Film Also This how Spider-Man is supposed to be also enjoyed that he cracked Jokes also enjoyed the complexity of his character glad they showed how he became our friendly neighborhood Spider-man also Ifans played a fantastic curt Connors also I was very empathic towards him seeing as he wanted to cure himself also loved Stones Gwen Stacy she was funny and not your typical girl next door, .Great Music By James Horner(Avatar), Cinematography By John Schwartzman(National Treasure:Book Of Secrets) , Costume Design By Kym Barrett(Sleepy Hollow) and Direction By Marc Webb(500 Days Of Summer) The Best Spider-Man Movie Ever 8/10

title: Spectacular Web-Slinger Revival! A Triumph for Spider-Man Fans!**
text:
"The Amazing Spider-Man" (2012): A Webbed Masterpiece Unleashed!As a lifelong aficionado of the iconic wall-crawler, I've **swung through the ups and downs** of Spider-Man's cinematic journey. But hold onto your web-shooters, folks, because **"The Amazing Spider-Man" 2012 is a triumphant resurrection** of our beloved web-slinger that leaves an **indelible mark on the superhero genre!****Plot That Grips and Swings:**
In this **stunning reboot**, we witness Peter Parker's **transformation from a high-school whiz to a web-swinging vigilante**. Director Marc Webb, true to his name, weaves an **intricate web of emotion, action, and heart** that captures the essence of Spider-Man like never before. **Andrew Garfield's portrayal of Peter Parker** feels refreshingly authentic, adding layers of vulnerability and wit that we've longed for.**A Romance That Soars:**
**Emma Stone's Gwen Stacy** is not just a damsel in distress, but a **strong-willed partner who complements Peter's journey**. Their chemistry electrifies the screen, reminding us why Spider-Man's personal life is as captivating as his battles with supervillains. **The tender moments between them** are as captivating as Spidey's acrobatics!**A Villain for the Ages:**
Enter the enigmatic **Dr. Curt Connors**, portrayed masterfully by Rhys Ifans. The **transformation of Connors into the menacing Lizard** is a chilling display of visual effects prowess, but it's the **internal struggle that truly captivates**. The antagonist's plight is portrayed with empathy, making us question the thin line between hero and villain.**Visually Dazzling:**
From the **vertigo-inducing skyscraper swings** to the **heart-pounding battles**, "The Amazing Spider-Man" plunges us headfirst into Spider-Man's world. The **camera work dances through New York's skyline with a kinetic energy** that mirrors Spidey's own agility. The **suit design itself is a testament** to modern cinema's ability to bring comic book visuals to life.**Homage and Innovation:**
While paying **homage to the comics**, this film **strides confidently into new territory**. The **mystery surrounding Peter's parents adds depth to his character**, and the incorporation of **cutting-edge science amplifies the allure of his origins**. It's a daring departure that respects the past while looking ahead to the future.**James Horner's Unforgettable Score:**
The late **James Horner's score elevates every moment**, deftly accentuating the emotional crescendos and action-packed sequences. **His music intertwines with the narrative**, becoming the heartbeat of the film itself.**In Conclusion:**
**"The Amazing Spider-Man" is not just a movie; it's a heartfelt declaration of love** for the web-slinger and his dedicated fans. It **reinvigorates the franchise with a dash of modernity while retaining the timeless essence** that makes Spider-Man a universal icon. If you've ever swung from a tree branch pretending to be Spidey, if you've ever cheered as he saved the day, if you've ever felt a pang of sympathy for his struggles, then this film is an **absolute must-watch**.**10/10 - A Webbed Triumph that Soars to New Heights!**

title: Different take - but still Spidey
text: It took me a while to get used to the new cast, Especially Sally Fields because she doesn't look like the typical older than dirt Aunt May, but they all seemed much more natural in their roles than the previous movies. The acting was top notch putting the heart and soul into the story. Some changes were a bit weak - like the death of Uncle Ben, but I can see them not wanting to have to repeat the whole wrestling thing, so it didn't detract too, too much for me. Sheen was terrific in the part, but I also was waiting for him to say "With great power comes great responsibility" I really liked the new moves Spider-man did, and the different ways he used the webbing. Garfield was great with the jokes - that was sorely missing from all the Raimi movies - the snappy patter is an important part of Spider-man's actions - not only does it get the ire of many villains so they make mistakes - but like Spidey said, If he didn't crack jokes in the middle of danger, he'd probably cry. I also liked seeing the web shooters return - I always thought that was a bad decision in the last set of movies to make them "organic", because if they were natural - logically, they wouldn't be shooting from his wrists, and he'd be swinging through the city by his butt.The Lizard looked different - but I can understand why, and it made sense because he's a hybrid - not a true lizard. I hear some people complaining about unresolved story threads, but perhaps they will be addressed in a sequel.I really had a good time at the movies seeing this, and would like Webb to return for the sequel. Good movie.

title: Good clean fun
text: It's good clean fun. I rarely watch these movies, but I like Sam Raimi.The biggest weaknesses of The Amazing Spider-Man are, unsurprisingly, the revisiting of the same material that was brought to life 10 years ago. Most audience members are familiar with the spider bite, the moments of Peter discovering his powers, and his hunt for Ben's killer. It also doesn't help that in the years since the release of the first Spider-Man, countless other super hero film adaptations have seen the light of day and mined similar material. At this juncture, the origin story plot has really started to show both its age and its overexposure. That being said, The Amazing Spider-Man does approach most of these moments in a different vein than the prior entry. A key difference is to focus on Peter's budding relationship with Gwen Stacy, Peter's first girlfriend in the comics but a character that was relegated to cameo status in Spider-Man 3. Garfield and Stone bring a degree of chemistry and involvement to the relationship and this element of the film feels stronger than the Peter/Mary Jane pairing in the earlier films.Garfield also proves a capable lead in the role of Peter. While Tobey Maguire largely focused on portraying Peter as a somewhat shy nerd, for lack of a better term, Garfield's performance enhances Peter's nervousness and captures the awkwardness of the teenage years, stammering in his dialogue at times and giving Peter a degree of uncertainty in his moments with Gwen. It isn't necessarily better than Maguire's turn, but it is sufficiently different to not feel like a rehash. Stone proves a bit more fetching and strong willed than Kirsten Dunst's Mary Jane, and her realization of Gwen is certainly the stronger female presence when compared to Dunst.The Amazing Spider-Man also excels on the technical front. The visual effects that bring the action sequences to life are impressive, to say the least, and the film benefits from the decade of development in technology since the first Spider-Man. The moments in which Spider-Man soars through the city and faces off against the Lizard are eye-opening, and prove viscerally involving. James Horner's music score is also a standout, providing a fairly traditional symphonic score in a day and age where so many films are moving towards a sound design influenced musical environment.

title: The Amazing Not-Quite-Spider-Man
text: All the reasons not to see this movie can be summed up in one sentence: at a critical point in the movie, Spider-man is hanging off a building and needs to be rescued, as he has suddenly and inexplicably forgotten that he can climb on walls.There are a hundred other reasons why this movie is bad, like how there's plot reset every thirty minutes that causes all characters to forget their previous motivations and never mention them again, but the above should cover the worst of it: whenever convenient, Spider-man forgets that he is Spider-man, and the writer and director somehow assumed that you would too. And you just might, because aside from the names and the costume, there's not much left of Peter Parker or Spider-man in this story reboot.The action sequences are okay (but not great), and if all you want is another generic superhero movie, then this is decent, but that's all you'll get: a generic, forgettable movie about someone with a vaguely defined set of super powers.

title: Complete Movie! First near-perfect superhero movie
text: Pushing the bounds of what Hollywood filmmakers are capable of, the amazing spider man packs both a huge entertainment value and excellent emotional pull. I went in to the movie as a skeptic because I've been let down by blatant plot holes, inconsistencies in the reality of the world, and characters whose fate did not really matter to me. However, I left this movie satisfied and full of conversation topics that did not include berating the director with criticism. This rendition captures the struggle of a young man bereft of his natural parents and lives with his relatives. His father figure was very well displayed by Emilio Estevez and when he died, I cared about him.Now... Peter Parker was much better portrayed as a teenager, boyfriend, hero, and son. Andrew Garfield pulled off Spiderman in a much more relatable way than Toby McGuire did in the Rami version. The banter, physique, intelligence, and emotion were much more real as portrayed by Garfield. His social awkwardness with Emma Stone was about as quintessential an example of nervous first love as they come. You felt like you understood their relationship and interaction (Emma Stone was cast perfectly as Gwen Stacy). The combat and action was easy to follow, more tight, and seemed more real. Each action throughout the movie was understandable and not outside the range of the characters that did them. The villain was Dr. Connors (Rhys Ifans), and for being a half-lizard man that acted on instinct combined with intelligence and rage, he wasn't half bad (pardon the pun). I enjoyed the character range that he displayed and the change from good to bad to not so sure was quite nice. The nature of the villain was the only thing that really held the movie back from superhero perfection.Overall, This movie was excellent and really makes The Avengers look as though it is merely a straight entertainment movie. I'd watch the Amazing Spiderman again and buy it on DVD as soon as it comes out. Worth a watch.

title: This is a an underrated addition to the super hero genre with great characters, villains and action
text: The Amazing Spider-Man (2012) is a movie in my DVD collection that I recently watched on Netflix. The storyline follows Peter Parker as a high school outcast and science nerd adopted by Uncle Ben and Aunt May. He is starting to get more and more rebellious when he is mysteriously bit by a spider during a trip to a science lab. Peter's life is about to be flipped upside down.This movie is directed by Marc Webb (500 Days of Summer) and stars Andrew Garfield (The Social Network), Emma Stone (The Help), Martin Sheen (The Departed), Denis Leary (The Ref), C. Thomas Howell (The Hitcher) and Sally Field (Forrest Gump).The storyline for this picture is very well written and depicts the emotions inside Peter very well. The cast is outstanding and everyone delivers an outstanding performance. Lizardman was a great villain. The action sequences on the bridge were awesome and the final showdown between Spider-Man and Lizardman was fantastic. The Gwen Stacey story is also well set-up.Overall this is a an underrated addition to the super hero genre with great characters, villains and action. I would score this a solid 8/10 and strongly recommend it.

title: Great movie that won't stick in our memories
text: Is it possible to forgive a man who has now seen the light? That's what I ask of you now. I, your humble reviewer, got a chance to see The Amazing-Spider Man for a second time. Only, this time it was in IMAX 3D and the last time I had been to the IMAX was in 4th grade on a class field trip. I know what you are thinking, "You mean to tell us you didn't see The Dark Knight or Avatar at the IMAX?!" Well, no. But, I hear you and those are on my list of shame, along with never seeing the Indiana Jones films. Jeez, I heard you gasp through the computer. Now, after basically destroying my reviewing credibility, I will try to redeem myself.The best thing that I overlooked the first time I saw this film was the score. The music in this film takes the audience on such an emotional journey that if you pay attention to it, it will enhance the overall experience. I think the brilliance in the score is that it's very subtle. It's not constantly bashing us with a theme over and over again.One of the things that I believe swayed my first review was my view as Andrew Garfield as Spider-Man. For some reason, I could not picture him playing the part and while I am still not completely sold on Garfield for the role of Peter Parker or as the Lizard says with great alliteration, "Poor Peter Parker", I do believe he is a great Spider-Man. His voice is perfect; he sounds like the Saturday morning cartoon. So, after finally giving Garfield a chance, I will say that he is better than I originally gave him credit for.Since I did see it in IMAX 3D with my great friend over at The Brew (you can check out his review here), I feel an obligation to comment on it even if it's the same story with the 3D. If you are watching an action sequence it's very difficult to follow and often blurry at times. However, when the 3D is used right, for depth and landscapes, it's extremely effective, especially on a screen as large as an IMAX. There are sometimes, though, when Spider-Man looks very glossy. That's not something I noticed in normal 2D.After reading many other reviews that say how poor or cheap the Lizard looks, I'm still not buying it. I think he looks good. The detail on his scales very textured and his facial expressions are priceless. During this second screening, some of the audience was actually chuckling at the Lizard. But, I think it was a good execution.One thing that did bug me was the misleading marketing campaign where the audience was supposed to get the untold story of Spider-Man. That never happened.But overall, after watching The Amazing Spider-Man for a second time at a different venue and with most of my preconceived notions gone, it was an excellent film. I think I knew that all along and just didn't want to say it.So this time I will give it a9.0 out of 10"Crooooooooootch!"O, and Emma Stone is still hot.

title: A Pleasant Trip Through Familiar Territory
text: When I first heard that Marvel and Paramount had decided to forgo Spider Man 4 and instead start over, I was far from optimistic. After all, it had only been ten years since the first movie, and Spider Man 3, although having its fair share of problems, was far a franchise killer. Reports that cost considerations were the driving force behind this decision also did little to reassure me. But have seen Amazing Spider Man, I'm glad to say I was wrong. This is good stuff.The basic storyline is mostly the same as the original film. Nerdy teen gets bitten by mutated spider, develops super powers, begins relationship with cute girl, and after failing to prevent his uncle's murder starts fighting crime. But in a major departure from the previous films, this time Spider Man finds himself branded on the wrong side of the law. Branded as a threat to the public, Peter becomes the subject of a citywide manhunt, led by Captain Stacy, who just happens to be the father of Peter's girlfriend Gwen.And instead of the Green Goblin, this movie features another classic foe who's green, large, and scaly: Doctor Curt Connors, the Lizard. Connors is not a bad man. A longtime friend a coworker to Peter's late father, Connors has dedicated his life to developing new medical treatments through genetic experimentation. But when he tests a new drug made from lizard DNA on himself, he becomes a hulking reptilian monstrosity, bent on re-making humanity in his image. And of course only Spider Man can stand between him and his goal.New star Andrew Garfield has done a surprisingly good job of filling Toby Maguire's shoes. His performance captures the nerdiness and social awkwardness of Maguire's earlier portrayals, along with the initial reluctance to play the hero, while expanding on the character. This version of Peter rides a skateboard, wears a hoodie, and is just a tad younger and more rebellious, bringing him more up to date without radically changing him. Garfield also has excellent chemistry with the lovely Emma Stone, who gives the impression of being every bit as bright as she is beautiful.The effects and choreography are every bit as good, if not better, than the acting. There's something exhilarating about watching Spider Man web-swing across the city. The raw speed of his swing and the sound of the wind whipping by almost make you forget that you're sitting in a theater seat, and I would love to see how they shot it. Even more impressive is the Spider Man's opponent. The Lizard is an absolute marvel of animatronics and CGI, beyond anything Hollywood could have done even a few years ago. The level of detail given to his scales and face make him as gorgeous as he is hideous, and he moves and acts like a real lizard, right down to the flicker of his tongue and the swing of his tail. And the movie includes all the good natured comic relief Spider Man fans would expect. There are plenty of one liners and deadpan insults, as well some hilarious physical comedy. And the scene in which Peter first asks Gwen out is so awkward for both parties that you can't help but crack up watching it. This does not mean however, that things don't take a more serious tone when appropriate. The battle in the sewer is actually fairly frightening, at times the film becomes almost somber. One scene in particular struck me as overly dramatic to the point of sappiness, but it was only a brief slipI'm still not entirely convinced that a reboot was needed, but the results were better than I expected, and put the series on solid ground for the inevitable sequel. With good acting, solid action, and cutting edge effects, Amazing Spider Man is a fun ride across familiar ground.

title: UNDERRATED MOVIE...
text: The best on screen Peter Parker and Spider-Man in my opinion. Not my favorite Spider-Man movie. But a very good and entertaining movie. I really like this movie and I think it's underappreciated. This is a good movie in my opinion and well worth your time. Definitely watch this...

title: While treading familiar territory, The Amazing Spiderman manages to bring a fresh and more rounded take on the origin story of Spiderman
text: In 2002 Sam Raimi launched the first Spiderman movie which along with 2000′s X-men pioneered the modern superhero genre. It has been 10 years since then and 5 years since the mostly disappointing Spiderman 3 hit theaters in 2007. In the years since 2007 The Dark Knight was released and Marvel launched a fleshed out multi-film universe; both of which have greatly influenced what is do-able in the genre. Sony is now rebooting the franchise by bringing in a new cast and director Marc Webb to put his own spin on the origin story of Peter Parker as Spiderman. Can this new take on Spiderman bring enough new things to the table to leave an impact or is this movie simply going through the motions?Read the full review here: http://wp.me/p1tyJd-cO

title: Amazing
text: I'm a little disappointed in the storyline, but overall, very entertaining. These modern hero films based on comics have similar problems. To the readers and stans, characters and settings are already familiar, so they want more imaginative and artistic efforts from the movie. On the other hand, it feels so unique or bizarre to viewers like me who are not dedicated to all sorts of comic heroes that so many stories can be jammed without any direction and without any resolution. There are always opposite reviews and reception towards hero movies. For me, I did not come for a high level of completion, message, or complex organization, and it worked for me. All the necessary information and development and iconic New York sky flying scenes are all there with great quality. Garfield does a marvelous job of preserving Spider-man, sweet & shy and strong & determined at the same time.

title: different but in a good way
text: The amazing spiderman is a new take on spiderman portrait on the character and its darker than the Tobeys spiderman but it works well with the plot and villain the lizard which is also a great adaptation of the character. Every actor on screen does a great job and the chemistry between Andrew and Emma as actors and characters really stood out perfectly. My only issue with the movie is the sub plot with the parents felt like a filler episode in a TV show because it didn't really lead to anything. The outfit for Spiderman was very different yet it really matched the tone of the story also it looked very good, personally I loved it that. The movie is kinda slow at the beginning but it definitely picks up and gets more interesting later in the movie.

title: Best reinvented Superhero franchisee
text: Peter Parker (Andrew Garfield) who is exploring himself in his childhood and teenage came across the old leather case of his father which unveiled the world of his anxiety for genetic science and possibility of cross breeds .His anxiety led him to meet Dr.Curt Connors at Oscorp who is working on regeneration serum. His experiment is expected to bring out revolution in the health science but one missing equation stops him to achieve his dream which becomes a cause of worry for his project sponsor Dr. Ratha (Irfan Khan) who is continuously pressuring Dr Connors (Rhys Ifans) to complete the project as soon as possible. Peter Parker being curious followed Dr. Ratha to his secret chambers where he find his destiny i.e. the classic spider bite  . Meanwhile Peter shared the missing equation of the experiment with Dr Connors which he learnt from his father white papers that could decide the future of cross breed and organ regeneration and the reason for which Peter Parker has to transform as SPIDERMAN.No doubt James Vanderbilt & his team worked extraordinarily in terms of story and screenplay to reboot & revitalize the Spiderman series. What worked in the amazing Spiderman is the innocence of the characters whether it's the Spiderman, Gwen Stacy, Mr. & Mrs. Parker and even the main villain of the movie, the Lizard. All characters remain true to their core without being dramatize, there is pure humane feeling while watching the characters as they feel & sense the same as we. The events seem to be more realistic and possible in nature.Dr.Marc Webb has done incredibly good job to relive the stale franchisee into a fresh storyline with the apt combination of humor, emotions, romance, adventure and very important more practical treatment of characters and story. For this movie audience has to clear that the first part of the amazing Spiderman has lot of layers to be opened in the forthcoming sequels like the character Dr. Ratha and the secrets of Peter Parker Parents. First part is more of an introduction to establish the baseline for the future stories. Overall The Amazing Spiderman gives you the perfect summer adventurous treat for kids & families alike, this one you should not miss it!For complete review please visit www.thecritiquelab.comThanks & Regards Yours AVA Thecritiquelab.com Your Views are heartily welcome

title: #ReleaseTheWebbCut Awesome movie!
text: Great retelling of Spider-Man's origin. Loved how it combined elements from Ultimate Spider-Man and 616 Spider-Man comics as well as having its own original ideas. The Lizard is not a great villain, but he is still memorable and better than a pretty huge chunk of MCU villains which is kind of sad. Another great thing this movie is that they made Gwen more than just a damsel in distress and she actually risks her own life to help Spider-Man. The swinging and fight scenes are also far cooler than any of the MCU Spider-Man movies somehow. My only real complaint is that I wish the movie could have been longer.

title: Spidey's Big Comeback!
text: Okay, so as a kid/teen I loved the original Spiderman movies, as did most of my generation. But the third film, with a dancing, half hipster/half emo Tobey MacGuire left me damn near in tears because of my dashed hopes and dreams of Spidey facing off against Venom (Not Eric Forman in a black suit.) This film, to me, has definitely rebooted a dying franchise and I, for one, look forward to more of Garfield's wise-cracking Spidey in the future. The movie had the perfect comic book feel to it and I love that they stuck fairly close to the original story regarding Gwen, Peter and Capt. Stacey. The Lizard wasn't a home run, but the way has story line got a little twist from misguided scientist to full-blown genocidal mad man was a good little kick. (pretty sure that won't spoil anything.)The movie starts out kind of slow, but the crescendo it builds into gives the story a little bit more realism. Half the movie is devoted to setting up the characters and their relationship while giving a few not so subtle foreshadowing hints of things to come. To me the only things missing were J. Jonah Jameson and the direct quote of "With Great Power, Comes Great Responsibility." but I guess the last three movies beat those to death. Besides, if there's one thing Marvel knows, it's how to leave some juicy stuff for the Sequel...~James

title: unbelievable
text: Having thoroughly enjoyed the spiderman trilogy, I had been really looking forward to this latest addition to the franchise, but was sorely disappointed. I hated it. The character development was practically non-existent. The film had barely any tension for me. After 90 mins I could barely keep my eyes open it was so dull, including the action scenes. The guy who did a review on this must have been watching a different film. What I loved about the spiderman trilogy was that each film built upon the last, to my mind getting better and better - the action AND the plot and characters. By the time spiderman came to fight the Lizard in this film I wanted spiderman to lose so there wouldn't be a sequel. The forgettable actor who played spiderman (can't remember his name) was 2 dimensional and dull, as was every other character in the film. The lizard had the kindest face I've ever seen on an arch villain. What ashame he didn't kill spiderman. I spent £10 on the DVD and gave it away immediately to a charity shop. My advice to you - try BEFORE you buy. I so wish I had.

title: A greatly under appreciated superhero movie
text: A greatly under appreciated superhero movie that takes pleasure in revamping Spidey into a similar yet welcomed, darker tone. Besides closely resembling Sam Raimi's first Spider-man flick, Mark Webb provides small modifications to the Spidey legacy that soley advances the web head's character. Andrew Garfield exemplifies a wittier, livelier Spider-Man through his astonishing performance, adding additional human movement to Spidey's swings which in all nearly surpasses the greater performance of his counterpart, Tobey Migure. Many fans disliked Garfield's trendier, hip adaptation of Parker. However I believe he performed exceptionally considering much of the negative comments are at the fault of the script and not Garfield's acting. Gwen was beautifully acted by Emma Stone who in favor clicked perfectly with Garfield's Peter, landing the adorable nature between two newely connected individuals. Rhys Ifans The Lizard wasn't unprecedented and at times felt severely underdeveloped, however his connection to Peter and his corrupted nature from pressure and ambition and later the toxins, all served as distinctive antagonist fundamentals that fabricated an entertaining Spider-Man foe. In addition, the CGI was flawless and aided in the engrossment of this gorgeous world making lizard people feel all the more real. Which conventionally added to the already beautiful cinematography that appeared almost too delightful for a comic book flick yet felt earned. The addition of Peter's parent's backstory was clever in constructing contrast between Raimi's and Webb's Spider-Men. Moreover this is an absolute banger of a movie and doesn't deserve the hate it receives. It may have it's plot holes but every movie does. Even if you're not a Spider-Man fan, this movie will still be entertaining.

title: A fantastic film that allows Andrew Garfield and Emma Stone to shine
text: To start this off, this review is absolutely biased. As somebody who grew up reading comics and generally involved in the comic industry & world, Spider-Man is not only my favorite super hero, but my favorite character in comic book history. Granted, there were some issues with the film in comparison to the comics, but they weren't at all hard to overlook in appreciation of, what I believe to be, a heavily underappreciated comic book film. Andrew Garfield and Emma Stone have fantastic chemistry as Peter Parker/Spider-Man and Gwen Stacy. I thought they, alongside the rest of the cast, did a wonderful job. The action and fight scenes are among my favorite in all of the Spider-Man films, with the stylized difference between The Lizard and Spider-Man being so stark in their fights making me love it even more. The fight scenes felt incredibly specialized to exactly those two characters in the best possible way. The cinematography was nothing to sneeze at as it did a great job of showing the vastness of New York City in comparison to everything going on. Overall, a film that I feel would stand up well as a traditional film, was only bolstered by one of the greatest and most notable characters ever in Spider-Man.

title: Good Movie
text: I actually really like this Spider-Man film. I like the serious tone of this film and really enjoy Lizard as the villain. The casting for Peter Parker (Andrew Garfield) and Gwen Stacey (Emma Stone) is perfect making for a solid Spider-Man reboot.

title: very good

Although the first-person perspective in the trailer is just a glimpse in the movie, 3D is excellent Visual effects are first-rate. Sister Stone has a faint Icon gas field, the most praised is Garfield, the acting is excellent, a pair of big watery eyes are lovely and charming, and the slender figure in the tights is really beautiful! !!

title: Did we really need a reboot of the Spider-Man films after Sam Raimi's great run? Probably not.
text: "Spider-Man 2" (2004) was one of the greatest comic book movies of all time, and even the problematic "Spider-Man 3" (2007) wasn't nearly as bad as its many detractors said. Besides, superhero stories are serial by nature, there's no need to stick to a trilogy. Why not just let Raimi, Tobey Maguire and Kirsten Dunst continue to do their thing? (I never realized how much I liked Dunst as Mary Jane until she was absent.)Because of the Christopher Nolan "Batman" films, that's why. "The Amazing Spider-Man" (2012) is an obvious (and unnecessary) attempt by Columbia Pictures to give Marvel Comics' flagship character the Nolan treatment. IMDb.com even states that the filmmakers credit "Batman Begins" (2005) as an influence.With all of that said, though, "The Amazing Spider-Man" is actually a pretty good movie – I'd give it an 8 out of 10. It doesn't match the charm, humor and sense of fun that Raimi and co, brought us; Peter Parker and Aunt May here and not as likable or relatable. (But Martin Sheen is awesome as ever as Uncle Ben.)But Andrew Garfield is funny and talented, and he does a great job. This movie actually IS truer to the comics that I remember. Garfield's great line delivery finally gives us the wise-cracking Peter Parker Maguire couldn't pull off. And the Spider-Man I remember from my school days wasn't quite the vulnerable wallflower that we've seen in the Raimi films – especially when thrown into the mix with characters like Wolverine or The Punisher.This is definitely an edgier, grittier Spider-Man story. He gets hurt. He bleeds. The script is slick, smart, understated and obviously aimed at a more adult audience. There's good sci-fi villain who is rendered wonderfully by CGI; he makes the Green Goblin seem silly by comparison. And the action sequences were damned good – we get some great, wicked-cool fight choreography that seems true to the character and even reminded me a little of great comic book fight movies like "Blade" (1998).This reboot does suffer a bit from the superfluous and laborious re- telling of Spider-Man's origin story. How many people are unaware that Peter Parker was bitten by a radioactive and/or genetically modified spider? How much more exciting would it be to see Spidey fight, oh, say, Carnage?All in all, this was a decent movie. To enjoy it, you just sort of have to take it on its own terms instead of comparing it to Raimi's flicks.http://ericrobertnolan.wordpress.com/

title: "Oh, no! You have found my weakness. Small knives!" - Spiderman
text: Peter Parker discovers an old briefcase belonging to his deceased father that contains secret documents relating to Oscorp and his old lab partner, Curt Connors. Peter breaks into Oscorp Labs to see if he can learn more about what his father was up to but ends up being bitten by a genetically enhanced spider granting him unique abilities.When i first saw this film at the cinema i actually didnt like it. Toby Mcguire was my Spidermam and the Lizard was one of my favourite Spiderman villians but i didn't like his portrayal in this film. Over the years and also following Spiderman No Way Home, i revisted Amazing Spiderman and its actually a darn good film. The first half is definitely my favourite as the last quarter goes a bit silly with The Lizard trying to turn the city into reptiles. The Lizard's portrayal in this film was actually really good for the most part, not a huge fan of his physical appearance in regards to his face, as I wish they gave him more of a protruding nose/mouth than just flat like they did... but anyway, still visually impressive. Andrew Garfield did an alright job playing Spiderman / Peter Parker but he is just a bit too overly emotional for me, particularly the end.He was certainly funny and a lot more physical with the comedy than what Toby McGuire was, but hes still not may favourite Spiderman. Visually this film is a stunner! I watched it on 4K Bluray and the colours and clarity are reference quality - if you like superheros and have a 4K TV this is a film to get and show off your hardware.Final Verdict: Action packed, funny, great CGI and a good villian. I could of done without ANOTHER origin story and i don't think Andrew Garfield is as good a Peter Parker as Toby McGuire was, but otherwise, its a great Spiderman film! Check it out.

title: Underrated Reboot, the acting carried the overall plot.
text: This was one of my childhood movies that I've decided to re-watch, and it's honestly not worth the amount of hate it gets! Of course it's obvious the animation, CGI, and effects are spectacular. But the new take the director took compared to the Raimi Trilogy had it's own set of potential pros and cons.I loved the expansion of world building, as well as more details on characters that you would hardly ever see on the screen. It makes the plot appear more serious and entertaining, like a miniature investigation that you have to piece together by the end of the second film.However, some parts do appear unnecessary, sometimes it feels like it was just dropped in the movie to extend time. Though maybe I'm just nit-picking.Overall, very fun! A nice fresh take without removing what made Spider-man, Spider-man. Over hated trilogy that deserves at least basic respect.

title: NERDYFLIQ - Amazing Spiderman IMAX Film Review from a 90's Kid, Nerdy jock perspective.
text: With this one coming so close after the other Spiderman it is hard not to compare the two. I tried to keep my blinders on but I realized that there is no way that I can accurately describe the movie to others that have seen the original movie from 2004. However I was a little let down because I really wanted to see #DonaldGloverForSpiderman. Hopefully someone will at least create the #MichaelCeraForShaft that we all want to see! Either way here is my breakdown of the movie. The plot was so extremely different that it served as an interesting twist. I don't want to spoil it so I'll just say the basics. It starts off earlier and builds the relationship between uncle Ben and Peter so you understand the depth of that relationship better. At the same time they glanced over his father's relationship that seemed odd because everything else was so well developed. I will let you make your own opinions on the rest of the plot but the way it started was a positive for me and let me get into The Amazing Spiderman's psyche a little better. The Amazing Spiderman is a nerd but he is not a geek. I think this was the major difference between the two movies. He is really smart in this movie and when he get's his powers he learns how to use them, practices, reads, studies and develops the webs himself. In the other Spiderman Peter was a straight punk that you hoped would win a fight. It didn't show the maturation process and he seemed like he got lucky with everything, and he always had an awkward situation with Mary Jane. In this one, he get's beat up early and doesn't have many friends but he still is pretty good at skateboarding and has a sense of humor. He also puts his game down tight with Gwen Stacy (they changed her name) and uses his powers to do cool stuff like skateboard tricks and dunk a basketball on the bully. The humor through the movie was dodgy, some parts were situationally funny, and sometimes the lines were good but for the most part I had an awkward want-to-laugh-but- they-cut-out-the-right-punchline-to-make-it-PG13 feeling. I am not the biggest fan of 3D because of the extreme fields of focus that it forces but they used it pretty well. The graphics and animation were seamless and I can honestly say they were top of the line and helped Spidey move in a realistic way. The cinematography was pretty good. I don't remember a lot of parts where I noticed and said, "this is an amazing shot!" but our level of expectation is so high right now, that is not a bad thing. Overall it was a good movie with a new version of plot and different character relationships. I think Toby McGuire was probably the best person to actually get the look down and the acting/casting wasn't perfect but they still delivered a good show. Spiderman was cooler, Emma Stone was hot, and graphics were dope. I recommend it and I would like to see the next in the series because I am not sold on ityet. And that's the truth Ruth, Osahon Tongo (@nerdyjoq) http://goo.gl/

title: Andrew Garfield is the best Spider-Man
text: I love this movie. I'm a big fan of Andrew Garfield as Spider-Man. The character dynamics are sooo good and just so nice to watch. I love Emma Stone as Gwen Stacy and their relationship. I love Peters relationship to Uncle Ben and May. The action is pretty good aswell. It's just fun to watch with amazing characters. For me its thr bst spider-man movie.

title: adequate
text: This is a decent reboot of the Spiderman series as we get a "refreshed" look at Peter's backstory. I liked the scenes where Peter gets bitten, the basketball gym scene, the subway scene, the battle with the lizard, the part where Uncle Ben gets shot, the part where he rescues the little kid, and the parts where Spidey's slinging through New York City. The movie has a decent story, an excellent cast, and good action scenes. Some people didn't like this. I liked it. Emma Stone was good as Gwen Stacey, and Denis Leary was great as the chief and Andrew Garfield was great as Peter/Spidey. Any superhero fan might like this.*** out of ****

title: I don't blame the actors
text: ====May Contain 'General' Spoilers===== I don't blame the actors for this letdown. It was really the script. The storyline was all over the place. There was no explanation about why his parents were important. His origin, their origin, nada. He just cried a few times when they were mentioned. The only thing you come away knowing is his father was a scientist that worked at Oscorp and abandoned him. Based on the commercials, there seemed like there was going to be a completely new door opened on how peter parker came to be (I think in one commercial the villain was asking rhetorically "you thought this was an accident??". I don't even recall that line being stated in the movie at all.) So there was no 'Untold Story', which I thought was the point of this movie. It was just a remix of the same story with a different villain. And the special effects were NOTHING to write home about. Basically if you saw the previous Spiderman, you already saw this one.

title: A good movie to watch, but not a must watch.
text: Watched a second day second show! Anyways, first thing's first. Andrew Garfield is not a geek! Missed the essence of Tobey Maguire. Yeah, this Comes from a spider-man fan! A fine start; delayed appearance of Spiderman made things even more exciting. Imran khan, however, was Sloppy. Uncharacteristic,I must say! Spiderman-girl was so-so. Great Looking but lacked in acting expertise! Didn't like spider-man unmasking himself in public so often. The biggest goof was lizard wearing an apron fitting to it's size - awful! The love scenes however, bound the Movie through a string! Great directing, camera work but Peter Parker did disappoint me (sigh). A good movie to watch, but not a must watch. Yet, you always like an old bottle of wine in a new glass.

title: Good and Bad
text: So much of a contrast that most people concentrate on the bad. The story flows and then screeches to a halt. Flows and halts. Needed a better script and editing. When Garfield and Stone are on the screen you can't take your eyes off of them. Everyone else pales in comparison. Still a good Spider-Man. Garfield is the best combination of Parker/Spider-Man in the bunch.

title: Does He Deserve The Name "Amazing"?
text: *Review Contains Spoilers* PLOT: Peter Parker has been bitten by a radioactive spider which gives him wall crawling abilities, acrobatic skills, and a "spider" sense. With the help of web shooters he invented, he becomes "Spider-Man". As all this is going on a scientist at Oscorp named Curt Conners finds a way to grow back his missing arm.In the process however, he becomes a giant human-like lizard and begins terrorizing New York. Can Spider-Man stop him before he succeeds in his plan to turn the majority of New Yorkers into giant lizards?MY THOUGHTS: The Spider-Man in this movie, I find, is a little more dimmed down than he was in previous films. I didn't like how he would tear up as much as he did because it to me he seemed like a wimp. Several scenes in this movie didn't need to be there or could have been done better and different. I disliked the scene where he trains himself (his wall crawling) while he is skateboarding and doing ollies all over the place. It just didn't seem right. I did like it however that the film was more "current" with Parker using the internet and his phone because you could connect with it more.Even though it is a new series of movies, I don't think the origin needed to be in it, or if it was, not make it take as long as it did. Don't get me wrong, It was cool to watch a different take on it, but it was boring because we have seen it many times again and again.The main villain, The Lizard, was good for the most part and looked pretty cool. However, I would have like to see a more lizard like face with a longer nose as well as see him in a lab coat like in the comics. The Lizard was not done as well as Doctor Octopus or the Green Goblin for that matter. Needless to say, he did wear the lab coat in two scenes, but, it was ripped off him both times in just a few seconds.PROS / CONS: It is good to see a new look on the character of Spider-Man as well as be given a newer origin story. His suit was alright, not as good as the previous one, but still alright. The Lizard was done well with just a few nitpicks like the nose and the fact that he didn't have his signature lab coat. The main problems though are almost all associated with the Spider-Man. He was whiny, his suit was passable, and his skateboarding was just out of place.OVERALL: 7/10

title: better than mcguire, still not holland. and why the Lizard
text: Um so hear me out. I think spiderman just gets better with time. Toby Mcguire is fun but feels cheap and cheesy. Decent Peter Parker, bad Spiderman. Tom Holland has the refinement of the MCU behind him. Incredible Peter Parker, great Spiderman. Andrew Garfield is kinda in between, doing a little bit better than ok at both roles. It's like the directors/writers are aiming for where Holland ended up, but decided to throw in a little bit of Toby for nostalgia's sake, and fell short. I really like his character. Something seems off, but it's still really good. The product is a movie that is more than passable. It's actually pretty good. Score is a bit boring, but not bad. Too bad they picked such a crappy villain. SERIOUSLY? THE LIZARD? What a stupid move. The CGI is kinda sketchy, but the green screen is harder to pick out than estimated. Solid, uhhhh we'll go 78/100. Even with No Way Home. I'm sorry but that's just how it is. The plot is so much better. Will watch it again.

title: Enjoyable but not the best Spider-man
text: This film does a really good job of standing out from the Tobey Maguire Spider-man films that preceded it. A fresh take on Spidey. Great idea. And especially great idea to star a different villain as well. Sally Field and Martin Sheen were spectacular as Aunt May and Uncle Ben.The biggest downside to this film was the casting choices for Peter Parker and Gwen Stacy. Emma Stone was already 23 years old when this film came out. Even worse, Andrew Garfield was 27! These are supposed to be HIGH SCHOOL kids! But they don't act, look, or talk like high school kids. That was a huge distraction for me throughout the whole film. If they wanted to be taken seriously as high school kids, don't use actors who act, look, and talk like college graduates. It ruins the authenticity that the film is trying so hard to build.Same goes for Tobey Maguire who was 26 in his first Spider-man film. But that's an entirely different review for a different movie.Other than that glaring casting issue, this is a solid Spider-man movie.

title: Unimpressed!
text: What exactly was this? A remake? Or a prequel? Not clear.First of all, who the hell remakes a 5 year old movie!? It's acceptable to remake movies from the 70s, 80s, and even the 90s! But the original "Spiderman" franchise is only FIVE bloody years old! Come on! If it ain't broke, why fix it? If it was meant as a prequel, then why are we seeing the same stuff we saw in the original, and why are all the characters so different? I honestly have no idea what possessed these people to produce such crap. The original "Spiderman" was (and still is) 100 times better, and it's not REMOTELY old or outdated.By the way... this is NOT an action movie; it's a chick-flick! Literally.And what's with this annoying tendency to cast 30-year-olds to play teenagers? It's lame. Speaking of the actors, they couldn't have picked a worst set of amateurs. I don't even remember their names, and I hope they're going to retire from the movie industry sometime soon, because they have no business being in it.The direction was seriously bad. Like I said before, it's NOT an action movie, but the VERY LITTLE action there is, is happening in total darkness, so you don't actually see it! Stupid and annoying! This is NOT the real "Spiderman"; it's a cheap imitation. Some pathetic 30-year-old wimp, pretending to be a teenager, is running around and getting beat up by regular folk? What an insult to "Spiderman" fans! Oh, and why release this utter nonsense in 3D if 90% of the movie is in 2D? This weak, useless, uninspired chick-flick was made for one reason only: to capitalize on the name of the "Spiderman" franchise and rip people (fans) off!Shame on you!

title: AMAZING LIKE THE MOVIE TITLE!
text: Finally this movie is completing its 10 years on 29.06.2022 (that is after 1 week) and this review is to remark its success.First of all talking about acting, so I never expected that Andrew Garfield can do such role after I saw him in 'The Social Network'. All of the actors just killed it and made this movie reach to the moon!Now this is a Spider-Man movie so obviously there would be comparison with the Sam Raimi Spider-Man trilogy. This movie had far better casting of actors than Raimi's Spider-Man movies but I want to clear that I'm not saying that Tobey was crap in those movies but it has its own place. This movie also had a better visualization of Spider-Man and the VFX also were far better than Raimi's Spider-Man films.Another thing that I liked watching this movie was that for the first time in Spider-Man cinematic history, we got to see a classic villain of Spider-Man from the comics (that is 'The Lizard') and also it had many comic accurate scenes. Marc Webb also killed it in directing the movie and all these elements in the movie made me a huge fan of this series.(Saying it again) Raimi's Spider-Man trilogy has its own place and 'The Amazing Spider-Man' series has its own place and of course 'MCU Spider-Man movies' has its own place.

title: "It's not who I am underneath, but what I do that defines me" - A Review of "The Amazing Spider-Man"
text: The Amazing Spider-Man is a film that tells the story of Peter Parker, played by Andrew Garfield, a high school student who becomes the superhero Spider-Man after being bitten by a genetically altered spider. The film also explores Peter's relationship with his love interest, Gwen Stacy, played by Emma Stone, and his conflict with the film's main antagonist, Dr. Curt Connors, played by Rhys Ifans.One of the things that I enjoyed about the film was the performances by the lead actors, Andrew Garfield and Emma Stone had great chemistry as Peter Parker and Gwen Stacy and their performances were engaging and brought depth to their characters. The visual effects used to create Spider-Man were also impressive and added to the overall enjoyment of the movie. The action scenes were also well-choreographed and provided some exciting moments.Overall, The Amazing Spider-Man is a film that provides some exciting action scenes and impressive visual effects. However, it falls short in terms of pacing and plot complexity. The performances by Andrew Garfield and Emma Stone as Peter Parker and Gwen Stacy are a highlight, but the film's simplistic plot and uneven pacing make it difficult for the audience to fully engage and invest in the story. Despite that, it's still a decent watch for those who enjoy superhero genre.

title: Hated it! with some qualifications.
text: I grew up with the original spider man story and I must claim ignorance of spider mans origins in the ultimate universe, so with that said, I am basing my whole critique on the original origin story. As far as the story line goes, this version is so completely off the mark, it does not even resemble spider man. The way he was bitten, by what, and how was not even recognizable. as a matter of fact, the whole movie was unrecognizable. This is why I am confused by the people who say that Raimi butchered the spider man story in the 3rd film (which I agree with) and then turn around and say this story was more in line with the comic? Someone please educate me if I am wrong. Gwen Stacy? No Mary Jane? bitten on the back of the neck? How Uncle Ben died? No wrestling? Flash Thompson trying to make friends with Peter? The whole story is WAY off. This is why I did not agree with a reboot, Do another spider man, skip the origin story and I would have bought it. I personally loved the effects but HATED the story...

title: Amazing plot and scenes
text: In this movie you'll see the beginning of spider-man and how he developes to become one of the most memorable hero's. He is an amazing student and his interest in science led him to a laboratory tour where he got caught up in an experiment and bitten by a spider that was part of the experiment. The scene of him discovering his power was a great scene as he is all confused and scared but overcomes his fears and learns to harvest and handle this power and saves New York.

title: Another Peter Parker and a more "lively" project
text: Sam Raimi's trilogy was good. Each of the three films evokes warm feelings, and often you think about how sorry it is that the fourth picture did not take place. But the story, as you know, is not a termite of the subjunctive mood, and the franchise has been relaunched with new actors and a fresh modern look at Peter Parker and his loved ones.Watching this movie, you involuntarily compare the picture with the works of Raimi. For myself, I noted that this film looks much more dynamic and closer to me in spirit, although I love projects with Tobey Maguire quite a lot. It was not easy for the main actor Andrew Garfield to compete with the Spider from Sam Raimi, who was loved by many, but the young actor made his character absolutely unlike the somewhat tedious and phlegmatic Spider Toby. In the new film adaptation, Parker looks like quite an average teenager who does not have any special problems with his peers, which is so popular to show in various films, where a downtrodden schoolboy gets superpowers and gives back to former offenders. Peter Parker in this film is quite like a young man who is no stranger to various problems of guys his age, he is cocky, cheerful, Parker is just going through a transition period, he happens to be what a teenager of his years can be.The new heroine Gwen Stacy is especially good here. She is played by the now famous actress, Oscar winner Emma Stone. It was after this film that I discovered the actress. The girl coped with the role perfectly, making her heroine as different as possible from Mary Jane Watson performed by Kirsten Dunst. Gwen is punchy, cheerful and sometimes flighty. This captivates the viewer and makes a couple of the main characters much "livelier", both in the course of the plot and in general within the framework of the new franchise.Important characters in the life and formation of Peter Parker, as a single hero, Uncle Ben and Aunt May were rejuvenated, which, in my opinion, also benefited the film. The excellent performance of Martin Sheen and Sally Field demonstrated that people of their generation can also be quite modern, much better understanding of teenagers. Frankly, Uncle Ben and Aunt May from Sam Raimi's films were more suitable for Parker as grandparents, which created a certain imbalance. Here the characters look more appropriate.I understand that a lot of my perception is based on comparing two different franchises and approaches, but I can't get rid of it. And I don't think that's a bad thing. Each project was created at its own specific time. "The Amazing Spider-Man" went by the time of creation and release after the famous trilogy. For this reason, I'm sure the creators understood that the comparison was inevitable and tried to move away from Raimi's films as much as possible. This attempt was a success, and the world got a different Spider and a whole different universe.However, it was not without some copying, when the main antagonist becomes a scientist who experiences an untested serum on himself and becomes an evil Lizard. Very similar to similar transformations in Sam Raimi films. But here you should rather look at comics, the sources of ideas still come from there. Therefore, such metamorphoses do not hurt the eyes.The picture turned out great. The presented story demonstrates how Peter becomes Spider-Man, what an important role the people around him play: uncle and aunt, Gwen, Captain Stacy, Kurt Connors. The film shows how important it is to be able to take responsibility for your actions, to be able to analyze and anticipate the steps of the enemy (Hello to Peter, who left the camera with his full name). The film teaches the viewer to think through possible steps and at the same time learn to be an adult, even if you are just a teenager. The plus is that in this albeit fantastic story, young viewers can see the consequences of human actions on the example of Parker. After all, it is not enough to have power, you need to be able to bear responsibility for your actions, because the lives of loved ones are at stake.A new film adaptation and a new story, a new film and a new world - director Mark Webb managed to show all this in The Amazing Spider-Man. This picture, as well as the franchise that began as a whole, were able to get out of the shadow of Sam Raimi's more than successful trilogy. At the time of release, and even now, this film looks modern. It is interesting with its presented plot, cool cast, colorful picture. Of course, this is a successful project that is sure to find its fans.8 out of 10.

title: Spidey is back and better than ever!
text: I was a big fan of the original 2 Spider-Man movies, just not a big fan of the 3rd film. I am glad that someone picked up Spider-Man again and told a different origin story. My hype for this film was through the roof ever since the first trailer premiered in front of Captain America Movie last year. The ultimate thing that people want to know is if this film was better than the original trilogy. Lets just say yes to that.This film stars Andrew Garfield (The Social Network, Never Let Me Go), Emma Stone (The Help, Superbad), Rhys Ifans (Little Nicky, Anonymous), Denis Leary (Rescue Me, Ice Age), and Martin Sheen (The West Wing, The Departed).The 3D in the film was a mixed bag of good and great. When the action scenes were not going on, the 3D was decent with the depth, but there was nothing really popping out of the screen. Now, when there is action, the 3D gets enhanced and it pushes really far out of the screen. The 3D and IMAX 3D showings of the film are you best bet to get the best experience out of the film.When Peter Parker (Andrew Garfield) is young, his mother and father drop leave him in the care of his aunt and uncle. Once he is older and in high school, he finds some of his dads old stuff and starts to snoop and get into it. He finds his dads old work partner and helps him finish his project to regenerate skins cells and regrow limbs and such. At the same time he is falling for Gwen Stacy (Emma Stone) who's dad is the police Captain. While dealing with the cops and the results of Dr. Curt Connors (Rhys Ifans) project, Spider-Man has a lot to deal with. I thought this film was spectacular. I enjoyed every action scene, story based scene, and romantic scenes. There was only one real main problem and that was the pacing of the film. It felt like they rushes the begging story line scenes just to get him to be in the Spider-Man suit as soon as possible. Other than that the film was really well done and well directed. I don't think this film will do as well as "The Avengers" did or "The Dark Night Rises" will, but I think it is a great super hero film. I can't recommend this film enough. If you are a fan of Spider-Man, than this film does justice to the Spider-Man franchise.Rating: 8.5/10Thank you for reading my review, any feedback is greatly appreciated!

title: idea of re-shooting a ten years old successful movie is a failure to begin with...
text: we all know the difference between spider-man and the amazing spider-man series but when the beginnings were so similar i couldn't help but wonder, whose idea was this? Granted, cast was better except of course the lead role spider-man. even the script was not good about his high school life and it only exhibits him as a spoiled child, still he can do justice the role of the spider-man but well he did not. Not so subtle allusions to original spider-man were not a good trick but an admission of failure from the beginning.as i say re-shooting spider-man was the worst idea and you will waste your money to see a worst version of a 10 years old best movie.

title: The Amazing Spider-Man review - no spoilers
text: The Amazing Spider-man review - No Spoiler'sMay not be "Amazing" but it damn well near comes closeBy Nathan HallBRIEF OVERVIEW:A fun-filled ride for the whole family though at certain sections with this been a 12a and some parents taking their little children to see it some children were taken out of theatre so please be cautious. A superb filled out cast, excellent portray of Spider-man via his movements, speech and actions/ effects. The lizard has excellent CGI and this CGI upholds for most parts of the film. The third act is a bit wobbly though returns strong at the end.........remember this is a Marvel film so stay during credits...Full ReviewWith the release of Sony's reboot on the Spider-man franchise it only comes to stand that it is inevitably going to be compared to the previous trilogy to which had its huge up and down moments this most likely been the case with Spider-man 3, and its terrible onslaught of villain over kill.Though as a huge fan of the Webheads antics since a small child and waiting to see this film a lot of promotional items were released maybe to an over extent people might believe but from what you've seen in the trailers and shorts, this is only a miniscule comparison to this title. Marc Webb who is best known for his work on the 500 days of summer movie takes the director's chair on this occasion and put across his term a more "realistic" Spider-Man.Of course no person is going to be climbing walls, free falling 30 storeys and shooting webs anytime soon.....maybe ha ha. But when it comes to his take on this film the term realistic comes in the way he presents physics set in this world and use a lot more on camera spidey-shots than CGI add in's though taken they're are still a lot of these in there, but his more humane approach to the title character and its following cast is what brings a more emotional depth off the bat to this franchise from Martin Sheen as Uncle Ben and Sally Field as a younger portrayed Aunt May.Alongside this the main hero himself Spider-Man is portrayed by British actor Andrew Garfield, whose first lead role in a film comes over almost completely superb from his frail beginnings as a naive Peter Parker and growing into the man with great power into Spider-Man who embodies all the heroic responsibilities. The comedic factor in the film has it's moments though not as many as announced would and also how its presented via it's trailers but nether the less when those moments hit Garfield really shines to how Spider-Man is always meant to be. Furthermore when it comes to action scenes and moments of suspense and acts requiring dramatic effect, with help from the script Garfield does shine as the title character. I just hope that he's given the chance to shine further if a sequel though almost inevitable will surface.Cast that is also included are presented by the ever wonderful and fascinating Emma Stone portraying the role of Peter's first Major love arc character Gwen Stacy and shines a lot more more than what previous occupier Bryce Dallas Howard allowed. In the film she is is not portrayed as a damsel in distress quite the opposite in actual fact. She brings a good level head and excellent acting chops to portray a strong female lead which in this day of cinema is becoming ever more present which is a very good and big step forward.Other Cast members include Rhys Ifans as Dr. Curt Conners/ The Lizard (previously portrayed by poor Dylan Baker). The film from the beginning portrays him as a surrogate father figure for Parker in some of the scenes but as the film transgresses his "evolution" takes a foot, not just in delivery physically but through his direct acting vocal skills also. To finally finish up the cast we also have Dennis Leary as Cpt. Stacy Gwen's father and leader of the hunt for the vigilante known as Spider-Man. His portrayal of the character tries to show the balancing arc's of fatherhood trying to protect his family and the heavy scales of the law tipping him in many directions when it comes the films central plot. Though his performance is quiet admirable and fun to watch on the big screen.The CGI in the film is of a top notch quality even at segments to which are heavy CG bound via the Lizard and certain scenes with Spidey's movement's but none-the-less is a top job especially the facial expressions and animations done for the lizard to which was criticized heavy for his original appearance with how people see him.The storyline does however have it's down moments but practically every film does, some reviewers have called it a twilight-esc Spider-Man film they are completely wrong and just using the central love connection between the title character;s as it's basis.......though this film has a more in-depth emotion take on love than the Twilight films have in the entirety. To continue though as this been a reboot we all have the "montage sequence" though compared to the original Spiderman film with Tobey Maguire, it actually shows the progression of the suits creation not just oh here it is and this suit feels like it could actually be made by a teenager where as the previous films were too elaborate in my books looking good but elaborate.The third act of the film is basically split into two parts and this is where the film starts to wobble a little bit in my opinion but still holds strong through its final segments.

title: Spider-man, Spider-man, does whatever a Reboot Can!
text: The Spiderman Franchise, having crashed and burned with the third movie, which had more villains than a point, is rebooted in this film. So after we've killed poor Uncle Ben again (this time played by Martin Sheen) we get about half a slow moving movie about awkward Peter Parker dealing with awkward teen stuff, and another half of the movie that is over the top, CGI overkill.The Villain De Jour is the Lizard, an otherwise kindly scientist who is driven mad by his formula in an attempt to regrow a lost arm.the movie is too disjointed, and it's not like we haven't seen his story a bunch of times before.I will give them credit for making the web-shooters a device instead of a natural ability that made no sense.

title: Surprisingly impressive
text: I was always a fan of the old Tobey Maguire Spiderman movies.......until last night. recently released on DVD and SKY Box Office is the latest movie adaptation of the comic book super hero. I was initially dubious as i was just expecting a remake, same story, same clichés just different actors, however I was impressively surprised. Andrew Garfield takes the title role and plays it so well and so much more convincingly than Tobey Maguire, and in a row with Uncle Ben and Aunt May he shows real angst that his parents weren't there to bring him up (great scene). Unlike in the originals, the love interest isn't portrayed like some drippy geek unable to get the girl, it came across much more realistic. The baddie, played by Rhys Ifans, was very good and the CGI creature was done very well. if you are a fan of the super hero genre of films or just want a good movie to watch when there is nothing on then you could do worse than take a look, I was very impressed and with talk of a sequel in the works I think it will prove to be more popular than the originals

title: One Of The Best Origins I Have Ever Seen
text: I absolutely adore the Amazing Spider-Man. The characters, the emotions, the struggles and the journeys these characters take are amoung some of the best in superhero films! Andrew Garfield, Emma Stone and Rhys killled KILLED IT!

title: A Modern, Awesome Spiderman!
text: WOW...was literally all I could say after watching this film. As much as it is a cliché, I was completely lost for words; my brain still trying to process the awesomeness oozing from it, just wow. I actually wasn't much of a fan of the previous films. Although good, I found them to be just a little bit cheesy. Cheese on food, great, on movies...not so much. It was obviously an origins story, however this movie tends to be more true to the comics. They made Spiderman, who was quite frankly already loved by many, loved even more. Andrew Garfield's portrayal of the character was immense. He was witty, slick and even a bit quirky all in the right proportions. His chemistry with Emma stone was amazing, a lot better than I was expecting. Both of them worked together really well, and it was the chemistry between them and the funny actions scenes that made this the movie to watch last summer. This is a late review, I actually watched it last Summer, but since then I have seen it at least four times more; I can't get enough of it and I can't wait for the sequel.

title: The AMAZING SPIDER MAN: Another great Spiderman? Or a New Spiderman?
text: I was very excited about this coming title. Indeed, I am a big spider man fan and I was reading its comics when I was a kid. Therefore, I loved the first 3 chapters. They made me feel like a kid again. I loved very much how spider man was presented, i.e just like in the comic book: Very shy, sensitive,humble, a bit confused, a sort of looser and very much oppressed by his boss. He also had very complex relationship with Mary Jane. There was also a strong and mixed friendship with Harry...So a very lovable and king person, with gentle character, high morals and excellent attitude. A model for kids, and even adults :) All of that is what made me love spider man, above the super hero and super powers. And I believe it is the reason for its success above super hero fans public. He felt like a real guy, with real problems, and a real life. Someone everyone feels attached and emotional about. His love story made many frustrated when he couldn't face his lover, and finally relieved when he did. So I am a real spider man lover, and I should have loved this new movie as much as I did with the others.So with this "new" spider man, I was wondering what would be new about it? I expected amazing 3D, and being transported another time in the complexity of Peter Parker's life. But what a shock! Peter Parker was turned into a confident high school teenager,and quite good looking I must confess (Better than the previous one I suppose). He has no job, no friends except his future girl friend. Also, the story seemed to have somehow changed, and this teenager is trying to find out more about his parents. Basically,this new movie has kept the "spider man" basics to make up a new whole spider man, lacking of character, humor, depth. There was not a moment where I heard anyone laughing at the cinema, whereas the original spider man always attracted a lot of laughter, especially with his boss. In fact, I felt it was a NEW spider man for a new generation of kids, aged 7-14 to make it look closer to their life interests and to help sell more merchandise. Indeed, the new spider man is in high school (almost an adult for the age categories mentioned above) and displays more his gadgets than the previous one. These are clearly identified in this movie, so the kids can get them in the shops. This new hero is good looking with a winner look and attitude, he is what we can call " cool", exactly the opposite of the genuine spider man. He shows off when he is angry, beats his friends at school, mocks the police, and displays a lot of arrogance. To me, it is nothing like the spider man I know.To come back to this new movie, the transformation into spider man has been shortened to few min in the subway, probably a cut in the editing to make the movie shorter. His uncle was also killed very quickly and his deep love to his aunt was barely showed, or at least not enough. His love for Mary Jane looked more like an attraction and admiration for someone out of his league. It was almost the case in the original spider man, but she was his neighbor and they grew up together. So there was a real connection and emotion between them, mixed with their trio friendship.The only positive point of this movie is it is obviously taking advantage of the new computers capabilities, rendering a much better appearance and action scenes. But still, the 3D was the slightly enhanced 3D most new movies offer, nothing like the magnificent 3D superman was given. Indeed, Spider man is one of these movies where you could demonstrate new and maximum 3D capabilities. I was expecting break through in 3D, but instead the action scenes were kept to the minimum, probably covering 10% of the movie length.To resume, the new amazing spider man is a set up for a new hero, with similar background than the original spider man. But it represents to me a transformation of the story making the character superficial, impulsive, lacking of emotions, which could match better kids and teenager-to-come ideals and taste. I don't believe any grown up or genuine spider man fan would fall under the spell of this new spider man. Just too simple and not deep enough. Now, many younger viewers who don't know spider man or who haven't read the comics may still find it is an "Ok"or even a good movie. And this is what the producers are tabling on: creating a new hero to suit better a new generation needs. Is it though really necessary? As the fundamentals and moral principles are still unchanged, and I believe there was no need to spoil a great story and a super hero with character into a good looking orphan teenager with super powers and the respect of his entire school.All other super hero movies kept the original spirit, including the latest avengers where nothing needed to be changed to make of it a block buster. I heard they are already preparing a second opus...maybe they should make it a "lego" one...At last, people would know who it is really meant for.

title: I think I see the problem here.
text: I'm a big fan of the Sam Raimi/Tobey Maguire "Spiderman" films. They were fun, light-hearted, silly, thrilling, special effects bonanzas. They were everything you'd expect from a movie based on a character from a 1960's comic book. They didn't take themselves too seriously. Even when people died, it was cartoonish enough that it didn't sting too deeply or for too long.Now, enter the Webb/Garfield "Amazing Spiderman" film and, Wow. Holy crap. This is dark, man- *dark*. It's not at all what I was expecting from a superhero movie. This really isn't a comic book at all, is it? It's a horror movie that happens to have a superhero in it, not a superhero movie. I mean hey, I love this film and I think it's great, but wow is it disturbing. This is what you would get if you let Stuart Gordon ("Re-Animator," "From Beyond") direct a superhero film. I'm not familiar with Marc Webb's work- and his resumé seems remarkably thin- but I would be surprised if Stuart Gordon, Clive Barker and Wes Craven weren't deep influences of his.It took me a long time to warm up to the idea of this film, and an even longer time to get around to actually seeing it, because I'm such a huge fan of the three previous Raimi films. I'm glad I watched it, it's very good... but it has little or nothing to do with "Spiderman" as I know it.9/10 stars because it really is a great film, but -1 because seriously, Wow: *dark*.

title: A decent movie, but a somewhat short reboot
text: This reboot of Peter Parker's story falls somewhat short of what has already been seen in the Sam Raimi trilogy, but one point in its favor is giving an index on Peter Parker's parents. Andrew Garfield is not a very memorable Spider-Man, but he is fascinating, as the first part of his story tells. The bad thing is that when everything starts with the death of Uncle Ben, this conflict ends up in nothing. Emma Stone is terrific in her role as Gwen Stacy. The lizard has a questionable design regarding its facial appearance, while the rest is spectacular. In part, this movie earns a point in favor for being more similar to the animated series of the 90s, but the film has a somewhat slow script. Fortunately, the special effects and action scenes are the most attractive and the film ends up being somewhat entertaining. It doesn't quite measure up to the Sam Raimi trilogy, but it's a decent movie. My final rating for this movie is an 8/10.

title: Oh, what a tangled web we weave
text: Based on The Marvel Comic Book by Stan Lee and Steve Ditko, it was appropriately directed by Mark Webb.Usually but not always the remakes lack originality and the following of the first. Well, this version very much surpassed any previous versions, and the character of Peter Parker (Spidie) is better rounded, and his background made the character is better told. The whole story seems better-rounded and consistent with the magazine.I appreciate the mix of actors, some well-known to many others well-known to followers. Each made their character come alive.I do not want to go into too much detail as the fun is anticipating the events. Some of us do not need to compare not seeing any original movies or magazines. So, it is well worth a look.There are several DVDs and download combinations of this presentation. If you have the opportunity to watch the extras they only add to the experience of the movie. I liked the voiceover commentary with Mark Webb.

title: Amazing movie about an American Character
text: This is in my top 3 Speaking movies. It features all the classic things about the character while also expanding his backstory. The Villain was awesome. The pacing was better then the original Spider-Man. I mean he doesn't need to become Spider-Man right away. Slow beginning May feel unnecessary but it isn't. It's got a great love interest, emotional deaths, suspenseful fights, top notch sound track. The only beef I have with this movie is that he shares his identity to early in the movie which isn't really like Spider-Man's. However I got over that part fast. I don't get the hate. It was honestly better then Far From Hone or even Into The Spider-Verse. All I can say is great movie. Aside from that one flaw I'll give it a 10/10.

title: http://realmoviereviews4you.blogspot.com/
